Don't ask me why, but it would seem that conducting Pachelbel was something he didn't enjoy. <br /> <br />The rest of the album, however, is very enjoyable, smooth, melodious, and thoroughly enjoyable and commendable. <br /> <br />So, in a nutshell: if you've had it with Pachelbel's Canon in D, this is a great recording for you. B000E8QVWY|5.0|Walk the line by Director James Mangold (I love all his movies) is a gorgeous tale of the love affair between Johnny Cash and June Carter. Joaquin Phoenix and Reese Witherspoon are well-suited in their roles here. The film focuses mainly on how John and June met and toured together through the years and the start of their affair while he was still married to his first wife. Also talks about Johnny's addiction to pills and his unhealthy relationship with his father. Witherspoon received an oscar for her role, a much-derserved award for this talented actress. Phoenix is wonderful as well, he sure has Cash's mannerisms down to a T. John and June would eventually get married and spend 35 years in wedded bliss til their deaths took form. Walk the Line has solid writing, terrific acting, and a positive message that anyone know matter rich or poor can overcome old demons and survive. Beautiful love story, buy this film.

I wouldn't have wanted anyone else to play Aeon but her, to be honest.<br /><br />But, alas, looking like a character doesn't necessarily mean that you will embody that character.<br /><br />The story takes place in the very far future as the last remaining humans build a city to house the last survivors of the population. Aeon, mingled in with the society, visits her sister often and has the feeling that the regime has been hiding something. Especially since people are dissapearing with no explanation for it.<br /><br />Now, as I was watching this movie, I couldn't help but notice that it had a similar outline to that of V FOR VENDETTA. But, sadly, this is no V FOR VENDETTA.<br /><br />The action was good and well cherographed, I admit.<br /><br />The costumes and plot were also very well done.<br /><br />If anything, I like the premise and story of this timeless character and movie.<br /><br />But, with this movie, I think they thrusted the audience too fast into the movie without really spending the time or effort in re-telling the backstory of Aeon and the Regime. Some parts I got confused as to whether everything was comprehendible or if it was just me. STAR WARS had a similar approach, introducing gadgets that need no explaination, but Aeon somehow falls flat in this department. It's not that the gagdets aren't well explained, it's just that they seem to almost pop out of nowhere or need MORE explaining.<br /><br />I'm Not saying that I hate the movie. I think that they did a spectacular job . . . but they could've done better. They could've spent more time with the backstory, becuase, in essence, that's what keeps us all interested in the characters. And I think that they could've at least spent more time on how the story would unfold. Each frame was not like a painting like it was in V FOR VENDETTA.<br /><br />It almost seems, when watching this movie, that they left something out or something was missing for the grand masterpiece. Thankfully, this doesn't hurt Charlize's career in any way but the film needs a lot of work still.<br /><br />I say, that if you are a hardcore Aeon Flux fan, that these things won't matter much. But, if you are a person who has never really been into the series, it may take you a long while to warm up to these characters. You may have to watch the original series and then come back to this movie in order to fully appreciate it more.<br /><br />I'd say that 40% of the movie was hype.<br /><br />Final verdict: Needs more history. Still good though.ckstory, becuase, in essence, that's what keeps us all interested in the characters. And I think that they could've at least spent more time on how the story would unfold. B000024D4R|5.0|Roger Waters was angry in 1977. He had grown cynical with a music industry, that like the film industry, pandered to the lowest common denominator and were, for sake of profit, sucking the soul and creativity out of the art form. Roger saw mankind as falling into one of three categories of Orwellian metaphors, dogs, pigs, and sheep. I wont delve too far into that because other, better, reviewers beat me to it here and their reviews of this album make my own eloquence pale in comparison. Suffice it to say that no matter what category you fall into, it's not a favorable outlook. I don't know if I'm a dog or a pig. What I do know with ironclad certainty, is that I'm not a sheep. <br /> <br />Sheep would, as teenagers, submit to peer pressure and listen to Pink Floyd then as irrelevant middle aged men, listen to Beyonce in some desperate pathetic grasp at fading youth. God bless the Internet. For were it not for the Internet, simpleton doofus sheep like these would have no forum to vent their thoughtless bleating. <br /> <br />Rock music isn't about \\"having a good time\\". It, like all other musical genres, is about expression, or should be about expression. Michelangelo sculpted the Pieta as his expression of devout love for God. Roger Waters, with Pink Floyd, created this breathtaking album to consciously express his loathing for mankind and consciously or subconsciously express his self-loathing. A loathing that someone giving this album 1 star and an album by Beyonce 4 stars would seem to justify. If you're incapable of the music in your life having a higher purpose than \\"having a good time\\", I would urge you to go back to Beyonce and her passionless test pattern music and placate your simple soul.  <br /> <br />I guess that makes me guilty of looking down my nose at my fellow man. Judgmentalism and pretentiousness are not the same thing.  <br /> <br />Anyone who gives this stunning masterpiece 1 star to attack this great band while saying nothing about this particular CD, and most laughably of all, questioning the quality of the musicianship of the band members instantly, irrevocably and permanently damns their opinion on ALL matters to obsolescence. Pink Floyd have their detractors. And I have met many musicians who didn't care for Pink Floyd. Something as subjective as music will make legions of people not care for something no matter it's level of quality. But I have never met ANYONE who knew anything about music question Pink Floyd's musicianship. <br /> <br />Look at the other reviews and notice how many Pink Floyd fans use the word \\"underrated\\". It's the prevailing theme. It is also interesting to me that it's often said David Gilmour and the other members of Floyd besides Roger had little input in the creation of this album. That may be so but it's Gilmour's finest hour in a band with Waters. It's easily Floyd's heaviest and most guitar driven work. This is Pink Floyd's angriest and saddest album and quite possibly Pink Floyd's greatest album. <br /> <br />I pray that time has tempered Roger Water's seething hatred. I also pray that eventually time will temper mine and allow me to suffer fools gladly and be able to read the reviews of morons and not feel compelled to write one of my own in rebuttal. <br /> <br />Buy this CD and take a stand against the inexorable march of stupidity in pop culture.

1592401791|4.0|This book is a good companion piece to the three \\"Beatle Anthologies\\", but it should be taken (read) with a grain of salt.<br /><br />EMI Studios in London serves as the backdrop for most of this book.  Geoff Emerick was hired there to train as a recording engineer, shortly before the Beatles first began making hits.  Emerick is uniquely qualified to write about the Beatles recording processes--- first as an observer, and then as an integral part of their later recordings.<br /><br />The distance between Emerick and the Beatles is key to this book.  His interactions with the group took place almost solely within the confines of what later came to be called \\"Abbey Road Studios\\" .  As an engineer Emerick wore a white lab coat,  and most of the time was positioned in an upper level, apart from the musicians.<br /><br />Emerick was a talented and resourceful engineer whose contributions became a big component of the \\"Beatle sound\\".  Part of his motivation for this book, it seems, is to lay out for posterity the many innovations he developed and how they enhanced  some of the Beatles' finest records.<br /><br />It's a very interesting read that will resonate with any Beatles fan.  On the downside, Emerick  comes across as rather stuffily conservative in his estimations of both the recordings, and the Beatles themselves.  He forms a bond only with Paul McCartney, and asserts that from the beginning, McCartney was the leader of the group (!)  It's quite telling that he titles the book after a McCartney song from \\"Revolver\\", the first  Beatle album that he (Emerick) engineered.<br /><br />John Lennon does get slighted a bit here, there and elsewhere, probably because for the most part his compositions weren't as lush and as likely to benefit from Mr. Emerick's services.  Thus, Emerick is dismissive of Lennon's 'rushed-out' song, \\"She Said, She Said\\",  which I think is a radically brilliant song compared to \\"Here, There, and Everywhere.\\"<br /><br />I am also one of the Beatles fans (that Emerick again dismisses) who love the \\"White Album\\".  Emerick finds the \\"White Album\\" to be anarchic...not understanding that many fans cherish it precisely because of  its breadth, and yes, its anarchy.<br /><br />Emerick more than once explains the role of an engineer as that of \\"making an environment in which an artist may flourish.\\"  But, he doesn't seem to understand that  John Lennon of all the Beatles most exemplified the temperament and conceptual thinking of an artist.  He instead is drawn to Paul McCartney, because like himself McCartney is a superior technician.... and because he's an affable bloke.  Emerick finds the other three Beatles surly, to different degrees.<br /><br />My assessment as I read the book was that Geoff Emerick is a classic \\"passive-aggressive.\\"  He praises all the Beatles with one hand, and [..]slaps them with the other--with the exception of Paul.  He also finds both kind and unkind things to say about producer George Martin.<br /><br />My advice, then, is to weigh this book along with all the rest of the accounts written about the Beatles.  It's another piece of the puzzle, but it probably isn't the definitive story.

B00003CXC7|5.0|For me, the most interesting aspect of this film was the relationship between the roles of James Stewart and Grace Kelly. Her behavior is even more unexplained when he tells her openly that if they parted, he would not miss her.  Yet she comes back!  And she does not impress as a submissive character, so why does she bother with him?<br /><br />I believe there is a power game between them, and her pride is hurt when he does not throw himself at her feet, perhaps he is the first man to resist her charms.  She doesn't know why but wants to discover, and she is determined to bring him to his knees, with him offering the wedding ring.  Once that happens, her game will be won and she would leave.  We can see how she takes an upper hand in the final scene, after her heroic break-in to the murderer's apartment, after that james' hero has no chance but to surrender, and immediately, as he is sleeping so obediently, like a baby, and in her care, she discards the book of their agreed-upon exotic voyages that she promised to him and turns instead to the most recent issue of Bazaar, her TRUE passion of fashion!!!  What a great battle of two egos, and poor James is totally defeated.<br /><br />His weakness and impotency is finally reveled in a scene when he sees her straggling with the murderer, and James does nothing except pathetically screaming, he is so passive at this moment, that we know his deep-hidden secret of incapacity, which is a source of his rudeness and cold reaction towards her.  We know that the power table is turning then, when she becomes a heroine and he is just a hopeless spectator and coward.  She is clearly the winner of the game.<br /><br />The film is a physiological masterpiece, and is worth watching alone for Grace's gowns..  <br /> <br />The film is a physiological masterpiece, and is worth watching alone for Grace's gowns. <br />    <br />

0553103547|4.0|A Game of Thrones is quite a book. I almost didn't write a review of it, considering all the long and lengthy and accurate one's already written. But then again, why not add my two cents?<br /><br />This certainly is dark, fatalistic material. The characters are complex, the plot intricate, the writing solid. The world Martin creates is large and incredibly imaginative. By the end of a book like this there are a whole host of foreign names and expressions floating around in your mind. Images also, that haunt and taunt.<br /><br />I say \\"taunt\\" because this book doesn't wrap much of anything up. There is some plot resolution, but not much. Really, it just stops. I would've liked to have finished with a little more feeling that I'd read a complete book. This isn't that; it's a volume, and by the end if it's succeeded for you at all you're keen to get your hands on the next volume. I mean, some of the main characters in this never even meet, never effect each other at all. There stories play out in very different places. The only reason that works is because you know that they will eventually come together, maybe in book two, three, four...<br /><br />One thing I wouldn't have minded more of is description of battles. I loved Durham's Pride of Carthage for how intricate and massive and detailed the battles were, and I think Steven Pressfield does large scale battles well too. Those authors aren't writing fantasy, but after reading them I have a higher bar for how to describe epic warfare. Martin doesn't really do the big picture when it comes to the battles. He sort of just tells you what happens, or has somebody bring the news. This isn't a big complaint, but it's one reason this doesn't have the cinematic heft of Lord of the Rings.<br /><br />Anyway, the bottom line is that Martin has written an intelligent, complex novel that shows how gritty and imaginative fantasy can be. I'm a person who likes some genre writing (sci-fi, crime included), but I still want authors to buck against the norms and keep it interesting. Martin does that. I'm not going to buy the next book straight away, but it's nice to know that it's out there. In a few months I'll probably get a hankering to get back into this. Truth be known, I really want to see what lies beyond the Wall...authors to buck against the norms and keep it interesting. Martin does that. I'm not going to buy the next book straight away, but it's nice to know that it's out there. In a few months I'll probably get a hankering to get back into this. Truth be known, I really want to see what lies beyond the Wall...

A great Sunday morning album.
0321344758|5.0|Last term during graduate course of HCI (Human computer interaction), my professor made a WebCT forum thread called \\"HCI Resources\\". Students were to post entries ranging from web based HCI resources to newspaper articles and books which they've found useful. Krug's \\"Don't make me think\\" subtitled as \\"A common sense approach to web usability\\" has made quite a mark among the listings by multiple mentions and was highlighted in several other assignment posts. This is when I started reading it and despite the common belief that technical books are selective reads, \\"Don't make me think\\" is an addictive page turner in its right.<br /><br />Krug's book is generally based on KIS (Keep it simple) principle and is an easy read. Like the topic, book is aesthetically well designed and organized into distinct chapters addressing different topics of web usability and HCI in general.  Chapter titles are not your-usual-everyday-headlines but rather Daily Onion style ones depicting the theme discussed in the chapter. Krug's laws of usability may seem like common sense to most of us but you'd be amazed to see how many websites around us don't follow these simple guidelines to enhance the user experience.<br /><br />This two hundred page book is divided into eleven chapters and definitely deserves to be called \\"an illustrated guide on making your web presence meaningful!\\" Steve Krug has worked hard in providing us concrete details and no-fluff advice on all things web usability. With gentle wit and humor, he emphasizes on web designing for scanning instead of reading, presenting simple mindless choices to user, providing meaningful and short text and realization of business requirements for frequent changes. Along with pertaining illustrations, author has provided the reader interesting scenarios, comments, usability testing advice and web accessibility measures. For a web designer, developer, an application development manager or a technology devout CTO, this is a mind-opener towards realization of HCI's importance in the business. \\"Don't make me think\\" makes you think how important it is to understand that usability is not the enemy of design and contrary to common belief, it augments a good design. Among several acclaimed HCI books (for instance \\"User Interface Design and Evaluation - Morgan Kaufmann 2005, ISBN: 0-12-088436-4\\") and ACM papers I have been through, I've found Krug's laws to be most relevant and practical. It's a highly recommended reading for web designers, content managers, web developers and all others who utilize web as core business tool or accessorize on it.wards realization of HCI's importance in the business. \\"Don't make me think\\" makes you think how important it is to understand that usability is not the enemy of design and contrary to common belief, it augments a good design. Among several acclaimed HCI books (for instance \\"User Interface Design and Evaluation - Morgan Kaufmann 2005, ISBN: 0-12-088436-4\\") and ACM papers I have been through, I've found Krug's laws to be most relevant and practical. It's a highly recommended reading for web designers, content managers, web developers and all others who utilize web as core business tool or accessorize on it.
0446677450|3.0|way, way oversimplified.  This book had some interesting thoughts, and certainly a bit (and by a bit I mean a SMALL amount) of original insight, but it lacked any real depth or practical content.  The lessons taught here in 200 pages could have been easily presented in the course of about 40, but instead, they are repeated, reworded, and regurgitated over and over and over again to the point of near exhaustion.  The result is unfortunate--I was very interested for the first 50 or so pages, but after that the book became very tedious.  Add to that the co-author's poor writing style and 200 pages is asking an awful lot, even from someone who enjoys reading as much as I do. <br /> <br />I don't mean to say that this book is without its merits.  I enjoy reading financial books, and, having had it recommended to me several times by various people, decided to give it a shot.  As I said, I was at first intrigued.  Kiyosaki has some interesting points, but again those points are driven home over and over again.   <br /> <br />The problem I have is that I can sum up in one paragraph what I was able to get out of a book 200 pages long.  To become wealthy one needs to acquire true assets, those that increase cash flow without increasing monthly liabilities.  The best assets are the ones that create income without demanding too much of your time, such as stocks that grow or real estate that is managed for you.  Your house, a fancy car, or any other luxuries detract from cash flow, so you should never acquire those if you cannot afford to pay for them.  Set yourself up to receive excess income every month, reinvest that income in something that will actually make you money, and repeat until you're wealthy.   <br /> <br />In other words, invest and save all you can and live within your means.  Pretty simple.  The issue I have, I guess, is that this is all common sense.  The author has a few original thoughts that I was certainly appreciative of, but overall this book tells you what you should already know.  I recommend reading it if you really don't understand anything about managing your finances, and if you truly cannot grasp the concept of building assets and managing liabilities.  If that is the case, the oversimplified diagrams and watered-down examples will benefit you, I suppose.  If not, I wouldn't worry about it.  Reading a couple of Kiyosaki's columns on Yahoo Finance will give you all the insight into his theory you need.

It's the story of men at war in the Desert. But never do we see battle sequences portrayed in movies like \\"Saving Private Ryan\\", \\"Full Metal Jacket\\", or even \\"Cold Mountain\\". This movie is extremely entertaining, the performances are great, it's funny, and it's probably one of the biggest Oscar snubs of 2005. Hell, this movie is better than \\"Capote\\" and \\"Good Night, And Good Luck\\". Anyway, the movie is based on a memoir by Anthony Swofford, played here by Oscar nominee Jake Gylenhaal (Best Supporting Actor, Brokeback Mountain). The movie opens with Swofford (or Swoff) in boot camp. The boot camp is instantly reminiscent of the one in \\"Full Metal Jacket\\" except R. Lee Ermey doesn't show up and make us laugh our a$$es off. The Boot Camp scenes are entertaining, but short lived. Swoff is transferred to the Camp Pendleton Marine Base where he meets Troy (Peter Sarsgaard, in another underappreciated performance), Kruger (Lucas Black, the kid with the weird accent from \\"Sling Blade\\"), Fergus (Brian Heraghty), Fowler (Evan Jones, better known as Cheddar Bob from \\"8 Mile\\" who seems to be playing the miltary version of that character), and Staff Sargeant Sykes (Oscar winner Jamie Foxx). Eventually, Swoff and the other men mentioned are transferred to Iraq for Operation: Desert Shield. If you're expecting them to arrive in Iraq and begin shooting Iraqui's left and right, then this isn't your kind of movie. For some odd reason, that's why I like this movie so much. It's awar movie, without being a war movie. Besides the entertainment factors, there's also the political aspect of this film. It couldn't have came out at a better time. This movie takes place when George Bush Sr.was in office, but all the events in this movie could be taking place right now. When Bush Sr. was President, the troops were fighting in Iraq. Now, Bush Jr. is in office and the troops are fighting in Iraq. Do I see a pattern here? Anyway, as I said before this movie is also pretty damn funny. The showing of \\"The Deer Hunter\\" scene was hilarious, to me anyways, and the comment Fowler makes in the shower was pretty funny. All the performances are standout; Including Gylenhaal, Foxx, Sarsgaard, Black, and Jones in no particular order. The reason Oscar ignored this film was because it was overshadowed by movies like Capote, Crash, and Brokeback Mountain. Allthough the last two are better movies. Anyway, I highly recommend this movie and it's one of the better films of 2005. <br /> <br />GRADE: A <br />

0743454537|5.0|The novel, \\"My Sister's Keeper\\" is a tragic tale about a girl named Anna who all of her life, has been used as a lifeline for her sister. Her sister Kate was diagnosed with APL, a special type of leukemia, her parents plan to conceive another child so that Kate can have a related donor. Then that brings us to the present. Anna feels invisible. Like the sun in our solar system, her sister's health is what Anna's family revolves around. It seems to Anna, that everyone in her family is so busy worrying about Kate, there is no more attention left for her.  Anna finally has had enough of this treatment. She files a petition to be medically emancipated from her parents. This decision is one that rips her family apart. Also one that could mean life or death for Anna's dying sister. This book was filled with unexpected twists and interesting characters. The character's personalities touched me because they were so real.  I could relate to all of them in a way. I really liked the way that the author made each chapter be a different character's point of view. Although it was an overall excellent book, there were also things I didn't like about it. Like the fact that the book was so depressing. It seemed like every time something good happened, something bad would happen. Even though I liked the different point of views, it was sometimes very hard to follow. I would recommend this book to people thirteen years or older because it has some mature content. Overall I loved this book. It will be one story that will forever stick with me. It reminds me of how good I have it. After you read it you'll be thanking your lucky stars that you're not in that family's situation. If you read this book, trust me, you won't regret it!
0767805712|5.0|Gattaca is a seminal movie that reminds me of what is lacking nowadays with sci fi films. It's wonderfully written, directed, and acted. I have studied genetics, medicine, biology, eugenics, and philosophy. I can't tell you how many times this movie in some fashion is mentioned. I guess that is what is so powerful about this movie. The themes, much like the music, are recapitulated. Destiny, genes, life, fate- it's all so powerfully incorporated in the movie and how science/medicine thinks.  <br /> <br />It is no surprise to anyone that the discoverer of the structure of DNA, James Watson- once said, \\"our future is in our genes.\\" There is a genetic determinism that pervades our country, our way of thinking. Whether it is said inadvertently thru the way we are more and more reliant on genetic markers for labeling diseases or how we are nowadays discovering more and more ways to meddle with our genes. Science has in some sense become a religion. Genes are our predetermined fate.  <br /> <br />It is this issue that GATTACA hammers at or chips away at brillantly and relentlessly. There is no gene for free will/ for desire/ for ambition. We aren't just our genes. We are a product of our upbringing, our environment, and heriditary predispositions. We are more than just a sum of different characteristics, traits that can be tagged to a repeated sequence in our DNA. There is no science for personality or for fate.  <br /> <br />The acting in GATTACA is superb, understated (I know, enough with the superlatives). Ethan Hawke and Uma Thurman have real chemistry. They play their roles with ease that fits the speakeasy, minimalist style of the movie. Jude Law has easily his best performance in GATTACA.  <br /> <br />The music or score by Michael Nyman- swoons and fits the dark but ultimately uplifting mood of the movie. Much of it is recapitulation- the scores repeat the same themes of struggle, persistence and sorrow.  <br /> <br />I am also impressed in the details of the movie. The double helix DNA stair cases in the apartment. The movie's title is written in DNA nucleotides.  <br /> <br />This movie did not translate well in the box office but it had a real impression/influence in both our culture and understanding of science.

B000BCKFWK|3.0|***1/2<br /><br />Robert Rodriguez' \\"Sin City\\" is a highly stylized adaptation of the graphic novels by Frank Miller (who, along with Quentin Tarentino, assisted Rodriguez in the directing).  The film draws its look and inspiration from those old film noir movies from the 1940's, the ones set in dark, rain-soaked, crime-infested cities and narrated in florid fashion by a world-weary private investigator or gumshoe.  \\"Sin City\\" has that in spades along with deliberately arch dialogue, self-conscious acting and a visual schemata designed to knock your eyes out.<br /><br />\\"Sin City\\" tells the episodic tale of three virtually unrelated \\"super heroes\\" (played by Bruce Willis, Clive Owen and Mickey Rourke) who take on crime and corruption in what is, as the title implies, a veritable metropolitan den of vice and iniquity.  The three leads are supplemented by Rosario Dawson, Josh Hartnett, Benicio Del Toro, Elijah Wood and Rutger Hauer in various smaller roles.<br /><br />\\"Sin City\\" is far more about style than it is about substance, and, indeed, the story is the least engaging aspect of the film, often becoming repetitious and aimless and devoid of cohesion and unity.  The look of the film, however, is what keeps us interested.  Filmed primarily in black-and-white, the movie adds splotches of color at key moments and for various thematic purposes and relies heavily on rear screen projection to give it just that right post-modern/retro look it needs to be effective.  As in the \\"Kill Bill\\" movies, the violence in the film is graphic but so highly stylized that we never take any of it very seriously, although there may be just a tad too much dismemberment for some people's taste - though, strangely, the people who are killed never seem to stay dead for very long in this movie.  The art direction is less sensational than it is in many of these comic book movies, but the streamlined simplicity of the look keeps it from overwhelming the film.<br /><br />The child molestation theme that runs through the movie may be off-putting to some and it does result in a few queasy moments later on in the film.  Still, this is an intriguing and generally entertaining comic book movie that really does a good job recreating the look of the source material on which it is based.lestation theme that runs through the movie may be off-putting to some and it does result in a few queasy moments later on in the film.  Still, this is an intriguing and generally entertaining comic book movie that really does a good job recreating the look of the source material on which it is based.

The savant Raymond is probably in the top five, best performances in film or stage, ever.  Dustin Hoffman is outstanding, a talent in class by himself.  Actor Tom Cruise is becoming more and more an interesting fixture on the American media scene; i.e. a public personality.<br /><br />The more elaborate, dictionary definition is `autism spectrum disorder', why such unique description?  Because it's such a varyingly spread, or spectrum-like ROY G BIV of impairment it is a medical cause still basically poorly understood.<br /><br />Somewhere along the way, this movie picked up enough popularity to become cultural literacy, and in turn distorted what the public really takes for understanding the disorder of autism.  Take the book:  \\"The thing about the dog and ...etc...\\"  by Marc Hadden (upside down black poodle on pink jacket, can't miss it); that author actually tries to capture some of the myth momentum generated by the film Rainman and other spotlight stories in the media showcasing the so called `idiot savant'--not a very humane, and I think out of use label.  True freak of natural capacity somewhere in them.  Yet not all developed memory stems from people who are otherwise, more or less mentally retarded, requiring supervised care. They form part of the population of challenged and exception people who struggle with enormous disadvantages each and every day--and not pulling off feats of extraordinary computation or selective recall; by in large, incoherent and unable to interact in the mainstream.  Fortunately there is still enough humanity in this society to provide substantial care giver support and a happier life for them, housing and activities, nursing and so on.<br /><br />The mentally retarded, portrayed in this false light of super-human intellectual skills, is a double disservice deception:  it tries to disguise epidemic casualty in epidemiology as some heroic fantasy (in order to go on manufacturing those victims with obvious mass population fluoropoisoning), while it recycles the aftermath to chide the idea the public has any recourse to reasoning.<br /><br />That is unfortunately how ugly the situation is where populations are being parasitized by predators lurking amongst them. B000EULJLU|4.0|Since Tool are one of the best bands ever, and since they make new music about once every five years, I think it deserves to be a national holiday when a new Tool album is released. Ten years ago, Maynard and his band made their flawless junior album, \\"Aenima\\"; then, in 2001, they released \\"Lateralus,\\" which I consider to be the best hard rock/metal album of this millennium. And now, flash forward another five years, and we have one of the most anticipated releases of 2006, Tool's fifth disc, \\"10,000 Days.\\"<br /><br />Call me crazy if you must, but I expected better. Each new Tool album has been better than the last one, but \\"10,000 Days\\" is the first exception to that rule. It may be because we had to wait so long for new music from these guys, or it may be that it's over 77 minutes in length, but I kind of get antsy when listening to this C.D.<br /><br />\\"10,000 Days\\" continues the melodic path which Tool first chose to take on \\"Lateralus.\\" So, since their last two albums have been on the progressive side, it seems this band is becoming more and more experimental, and is thus kind of ignoring their heavy side. In fact, this might be Tool's softest album. Frontman Maynard James Keenan further explores his feminine side by singing in a very limpid voice, and his lyrics are quite a bit more sensitive (maybe even religious) than usual. Plus, even though guitarist Adam Jones sprinkles on a few good riffs here and there, most of the songs are quite slow and ambient. This isn't necessarily a bad thing, because all bands should evolve and change their sound, but \\"10,000 Days\\" ultimately seems like an overly long, largely anti-climactic and sometimes uneventful continuation of \\"Lateralus.\\"<br /><br />The album opens with two semi-heavy songs. The lead single, \\"Vicarious,\\" is quite awesome. It starts out slowly before a hefty, angular, almost explosive riff is injected into the mix. The song then descends and broods before again leaping in volume a little while later. \\"Jambi\\" features crunchy, churning guitars and a cool, robotic sound effect, but it ends kind of abruptly and doesn't really seem to go anywhere.<br /><br />The next three songs are very soothing and atmospheric. \\"Wings For Marie (Part 1)\\" has deep, supple, almost growly crooning by Maynard. But, unfortunately, the eleven minute long title track seems like a filler song and a \\"Lateralus\\" b-side. Track five, \\"The Pot,\\" boasts impressive, clean, almost falsetto singing and prog-ish guitar strings.<br /><br />\\"Lipan Conjuring\\" (which sounds Native American) and \\"Lost Keys (Blame Hofmann)\\" are both weird and somewhat creepy interludes. Tool had the right idea by putting the disc's shortest songs in the middle of the album like this (\\"10,000 Days\\" would probably be exhausting to listen to without these songs.)<br /><br />Next, \\"Rosetta Stoned\\" sounds like Tool circa 1996 (the \\"Aenima\\" era), because it features pounding riffs and a catchy, lurching/staccato rhythm. But even though this song (and all of the heavy songs on here) sounds quite awesome, Tool insist on plunging back into melodic territory for the proceeding song. \\"Intension\\" is sort of in the same vein as \\"Disposition\\" (track ten on \\"Lateralus\\"), because it has light, dwindling strings, soft hand percussion, and gentle singing.<br /><br />\\"Right In Two\\" might be the best track on this album. It is one of the few songs which actually has a memorable climax. Its  big crescendo makes the song gradually become heavier, and it finishes with big, stomping, almost Meshuggah-esque power chords.<br /><br />Lastly, \\"Viginti Tres\\" is a long outro which isn't worth listening to more than once because it seems like another filler song, and it goes in one ear and out the other.<br /><br />\\"10,000 Days\\" is a good album (it mops the floor with the vast majority of the other music released this year). But it fails to lift the bar for Tool (it might even be Tool's weakest record), it isn't instantly or completely satisfying, and somefans will surely be disappointed with it. So, for any other band, \\"10,000 Days\\" is a very good album, but for Tool, it's a sidestep.<br /><br />Also, be warned of one last thing: this album is a creeper. Having owned it for about a week before it was officially released, I know that this C.D. isn't very easy to digest, so it will thus take time (maybe several days of repeated listens) to fully absorb. But it will grow on you and sink under your skin a little more with each repeated hearing. So come prepared when listening to this disc in its entirety: be well rested, well fed, take some ADD medicine, and maybe even have a bed pan at your side.000 Days\\" is a very good album, but for Tool, it's a sidestep.    Also, be warned of one last thing: this album is a creeper. Having owned it for about a week before it was officially released, I know that this C.D. isn't very easy to digest, so it will thus take time (maybe several days of repeated listens) to fully absorb. But it will grow on you and sink under your skin a little more with each repeated hearing. So come prepared when listening to this disc in its entirety: be well rested, well fed, take some ADD medicine, and maybe even have a bed pan at your side.
B000EULJLU|1.0|Have the past 2 albums been an elaborate cruel joke?<br /><br />Lateralus made me laugh out loud. Aenima was Art. Lateralus was a joke. This album is a slap in the face. This mediocre piece of trash is an act of violence against fans that were there from the beginning and Maynard's lyrics wax like I imagine the diary of a 16 year-old goth girl sallies forth into the annoying cliche'd not-so-deep void of a contrived and generic sadclown soul with a limited vocabulary gleaned from years of other bad music and high-school dropouts for an emotional pipeline.  Though highly skilled and undeniably complex, this music sounds like the recycled crescendi of Lateralus and a few APC riffs with a touch of Audioslut meets the worst lyrics I've heard in years--worse than the latest cookie-cutter mainstream rap even and on the same footing as contemporary country music.<br />\\"So shine on forever silent vampire TV monster, etc.\\" or whatever verbally-handicapped nonsense you're vomiting over the rest of the band's hard work.<br /><br />The present over-all rating of 4+ stars is a perfect manifestation of how mindblowingly herdlike the general public is and how willing they are to blindly accept this tripe and line the laughing gladhander's greasy pockets. B000EULJLU|4.0|I am a big Tool fan, and although I do believe this album isn't as good as Lateralus or Aenima, it is not that far away.  After reading some reviews, I'm really not surprised some critics have bashed this album, but it is truly unwarranted.  Here are just some notes about the album that I've heard critics complain about:   <br /> <br />Although this CD does have many 'filler' songs, the length is nearly 80 minutes, and while these songs do take up a good portion of that 80 min, how many bands today put out a 40 min album?  In my mind, this should not be an issue, as every Tool album has these tracks that are not representitive of Tool's music, but of their uniqueness and interesting behaviors. <br /> <br />The music is still incredibly involved, so even if you do not like their music, it is absurd that anyone would try and bash it for not being good music.  Adam Jones, Danny Carey and Justin Chancellor are amazing musicians, and Maynard definitely adds a unique touch with his lyrics and voice.  Again, I understand not everyone likes Tool, but you can't say the music they put together is trash.  Although I don't agree with the whole list, there is a reason Adam Jones made Rolling Stone's top 100 guitarists of all time. <br /> <br />Compared to all the watered down rock that is out there today, Tool slowly crafts their music, which makes it better than some contemporaries, such as Disturbed and Staind.  In a recent review, someone compared this album to these bands, as well as Godsmack, which is somewhat insulting. <br /> <br />With that said, this is a very good album... my favorite song(s) is the Wings for Marie/10,000 days epic. <br />
B000EDWL82|5.0|Anyone who's really into this kind of music can spot the differences a mile away, between Editors and the bands they're often compared to. I'll spare you the name-dropping, since you only need look at 99% of the other reviews to see it. Be assured though, that they DO sound different. It just takes a few listens to realize it. While the guitar distortion and the vocal styles do sound a bit reminiscent of a few others, Editors distinctly have their own flavor. They use very different guitar work despite the similar distortion, they use interesting beats, they sing about different issues, and hey, get this...the singer doesn't sound like he's bored! Tom Smith belts out his tunes with *feeling*, a rarity today in bands like this. <br /> <br />Besides, if they're supposedly clones of a ton of other \\"noir rock\\" bands, then why do I like 'The Back Room' so much better than the other albums they're compared to?  <br /> <br />I think the people who dismiss them because of their sound haven't actually given this album a full listen or three. I \\"kind of\\" liked it at first glance, but upon repeated listens, this album grews on me so fast. I initially liked the single 'Munich' above others, but 'Bullets', 'Lights', 'Fingers in the Factories', 'Open Your Arms', and...well, the entire rest of the album has shown me that they're perfectly capable of putting forth a solid rock effort. <br /> <br />10 years ago, everyone at first said Stone Temple Pilots sounded exactly like Pearl Jam before anyone knew about 'grunge' or 'alternative'. How wrong they were then, and how wrong they are now; Editors have their own style, and 'The Back Room' is a gem.

B000EULJLU|5.0|Tool is back with a vengeance!  This CD is a lot more raw and in your face than anything off Lateralus.  Below is my track by track review.  Enjoy!<br /><br />Vicarious - I've heard a lot of complaints about this song.  Personally, I think it is brilliant!  Some people have said that it is too assessable for it to be Tool material...Schism anyone?  This song fits all three categories that make up a Tool song:  It has rollercoaster-like speed changes, weird time signatures, and is like nothing else on the radio.  Excellent jump start to the CD!  ~9~<br /><br />Jambi - When I first heard the opening riff, I honesty didn't think it was Tool.  It sounded almost too heavy and not something that I'm used to hearing from Adam.  Then, when Maynard's smooth and clear vocals come in, it is a perfect balance to the song.  Adam also introduces a talk box for the first time, which turns out wonderfully.  When I read Adam's interview in Guitar World I was worried it would sound like Bon Jovi, but thankfully it doesn't.  He makes it still sound like Tool.  Great listen!  ~9~<br /><br />Wings for Marie - This song reminds me a lot of Parabol in a way.  Not that it sounds anything like Parabol, but it just paves the way to a better, similarly related, song.  It's also a lot longer than Parabol and goes heavy one time near the end.  Awesome guitar riff that you'll hear more of in the next song.  ~8.5~<br /><br />10,000 Days - WOW!  Now this is what I would call a masterpiece.  I dare you to listen to this at night through earphones with all the lights off and no distractions.  The rain and thunder in the background will suck you into the mood and Adam, Justin, Danny, and Maynard will lead you into a false sense of security.  The lyrics are amazingly heartfelt and probably Maynard's most heart wrenching work to date.  The song, as well as Wings for Marie, is about his mother, Judith Marie, who had a stroke and was in a wheelchair for roughly 10,000 days.  This one clocks in over 11 minutes, but doesn't seem that long when listening to it.  ~10~<br /><br />The Pot - If I would have written a review right after I heard this song for the first time I would have given it a 5 or 6 at most.  However, after giving it a little more time, I have come to love it.  It opens with just Maynard singing.  Very shortly after, the bass comes in with him to make for a very interesting start.  This is the only song on the CD in standard 4/4 and is probably the most radio friendly.  I expect everyone will be getting a dose of it on your local radio station after Vicarious has run its course.  ~8~<br /><br />Lipan Conjuring - Weird lead-in full of Indian chanting.  It's okay on the first listen, but quickly becomes a skipper.  I blame my short attention span.  ~2~<br /><br />Lost Keys (Blame Hofmann) - Again, another lead-in, but this one is better.  It has a quiet guitar riff with feedback in the background and a doctor and nurse conversing near the end.  ~6~<br /><br />Rosetta Stoned - HOLY CRAP!  Now this song is wicked!  If you take \\"Ticks and Leeches,\\" \\"Hooker with a Penis,\\" \\"H,\\" and \\"Third Eye\\" and throw them into a blender, this is what you get.  It starts off with Maynard singing/talking so fast you can't understand what he's saying.  This is a monster song which sounds like two similar songs forged into one.  After Maynard says, \\"I didn't even graduate from f***ing high school,\\" it becomes a totally different piece.  It reminds me a lot of Third Eye from here on out, and even has a comparable riff with a slightly different time signature.  This song had to grow on me, but now is one of my favorites.  Be patient with this one, even though (like 10,000 Days) it does clock in at over 11 minutes.  ~9.25~<br /><br />Intension - Reminds me a lot of Disposition, but it's not quite as good.  It is slow with some barely distorted guitar playing and Maynard singing melodically as only he can.  While the song is good as a whole, it just hasn't grabbed me like the restof the album.  It sounds like this should have been on Lateralus or even a Lateralus B-side.  It just doesn't seem to fit with the 10,000 Days theme (my opinion).  ~5~<br /><br />Right In Two - This is Forty-Six & 2 and Jimmy's little brother.  It has a riff in it towards the end that is very similar to Forty-Six & 2.  Of course that's not a bad thing considering its big brother is an awesome track.  This is quite possibly the best song on the CD.  It rocks when it needs to and holds back when it needs to.  Danny's drumming is simply amazing and Maynard's lyrics fit the song like heated underwear fresh from the dryer.  They seem to touch on how mankind has a tendency to screw things up.  \\"Monkeys killing monkeys killing monkeys over pieces of the ground.  Silly monkeys give them thumbs they make a club and beat their brother down.\\"  Can't miss the Cain and Able reference.  ~10~<br /><br />Viginti Tres - Another space filler with weird Halloween type noises.  Scary, but skipped often.  ~2~<br /><br />Even though this album is not better than AEnima, it is my second favorite Tool CD.  I give the entire CD a 9 and I can't wait to hear some of the new material live!  My only complaint is there doesn't seem to be enough real songs on it.  I wish we would have gotten at least one more awesome song instead of three space fillers.  I would recommend buying it ASAP.  There maybe songs you don't like on first listen, but give them a chance because you will probably grow to love them.  Besides, its just music and music is supposed to entertain.  The entertainment level is high on this one and Tool does not disappoint!  I just hope the next wait doesn't last five years.d me like the rest of the album. It just doesn't seem to fit with the 10,000 Days theme (my opinion).  ~5~ <br /> <br />Right In Two - This is Forty-Six & 2 and Jimmy's little brother. Once a band has a decent formula they should stick to it. But as far as Metal is concerned it is very much alive if you open up your eyes. If Metal was dead there wouldn't be bands like Iced Earth, Megadeth, Iron Maiden, Metal Church, Helloween, Judas Priest and Moterhead. I could go on forever but you get the point. To name one I would say Moterhead played thrash before Metallica did like their song Ace of Spades. I did miss the guitar solos on Saint Anger because Kirk Hammet is awesome on lead guitar. But after a feel listens I did not mind. But to get back to this album if you are a fan of classic Metallica you may not like this album. Borrow it from a friend before buying it to make sure it will be something you will like.

0887307280|5.0|I have owned a small business for over 1.5 years now, as a one-man web development shop.  For the past few months I have come to the realization that my current way of doing things will lead down one of two paths: frustration at working all the time for not a lot of money, or closing shop and finding a job.  A couple of business partners recommended this book to me within the last two months, and so I bought it.  I can only say that what happened next was the best part of owning a business for me so far ... reality checks and awakenings to what could be.<br /><br />As I read through the book, Gerber pointed out things about how most small business owners are \\"technicians\\" turned business owners; the problem, we may be skilled in what we do, but now we take on multiple jobs that we do NOT know how to do.  The problem continues as we immerse ourselves in the \\"technician\\" work, but never actually work ON the business, so many aspects of the business suffer (sales, marketing, finances, operations) or just plain don't exist.<br /><br />In the first part of the E-Myth, Gerber discusses finding the balance of our inner selves: the Entrepreneur, the Manager, and the Technician, and the responsibilities that each of these roles must take on to drive the business toward success, as well as some pitfalls that each face unless there is a cooperative effort by each within you to work ON, not IN, the business.<br /><br />The second part of the E-Myth talks about the Franchise Prototype.  While this sounds like Gerber is going to talk about how to build a franchise, it's not!  What he discusses here is the importance of setting up your initial (and perhaps for many, the only) company the right way ... YOUR way.  This will inevitably lead to the \\"prototype\\" company, so that, in theory, you can take that business system and replicate once, twice, 5000 times ... always running the \\"system\\" the same way in each business.<br /><br />The third, and final, part of the book guides you through the system that you will think through, the business processes that make up your business system, so that the business can run ... even without you in it!  It talks about this becoming your own turn-key solution so that you have a business model in place that your system can effectively reproduce, as you need to.<br /><br />I took about a week to read through the book and soak in much of what Gerber has to say in it.  Gerber includes interesting examples, and the book is very easy to read and understand ... and most importantly, incredibly enjoyable.  While some of the text in describing his interaction with a particular business owner is a bit over the top, it doesn't detract from the primary message of the book.  I will read it again, and have already begun to get my (new) business system in place.  I now have plans to grow my company, and have the vision of what my company will look like.  The fog has already started to lift, and the steps are being put into place to reach the success that I have been longing to reach.<br /><br />If you have, or are planning to start, a small business, this really is a fantastic book, and should be manditory reading.  If you have a successful business in place, and don't agree with this book, please remember one thing before you post a negative review ... you are in the absolute minority of small business owners due to the fact that most small businesses fail within the first 3-5 years; due in large part to NOT having a system in place that helps drive the business.  Most small business owners would most definitely benefit from reading this book, if for no other reason than the awareness of where they are and where they could be.<br /><br />Thanks to Michael Gerber for such an eye-opening experience, and a viable blueprint.  I'm looking forward to the journey!ink through, the business processes that make up your business system, so that the business can run ... even without you in it!  It talks about this becoming your own turn-key solution so that you have a business model in place that your system can effectively reproduce, as you need to.    I took about a week to read through the book and soak in much of what Gerber has to say in it.  Gerber includes interesting examples, and the book is very easy to read and understand ... and most importantly, incredibly enjoyable.  While some of the text in describing his interaction with a particular business owner is a bit over the top, it doesn't detract from the primary message of the book.  I will read it again, and have already begun to get my (new) business system in place.  I now have plans to grow my company, and have the vision of what my company will look like.  The fog has already started to lift, and the steps are being put into place to reach the success that I have been longing to reach.    If you have, or are planning to start, a small business, this really is a fantastic book, and should be manditory reading.  If you have a successful business in place, and don't agree with this book, please remember one thing before you post a negative review ... you are in the absolute minority of small business owners due to the fact that most small businesses fail within the first 3-5 years; due in large part to NOT having a system in place that helps drive the business.  Most small business owners would most definitely benefit from reading this book, if for no other reason than the awareness of where they are and where they could be.    Thanks to Michael Gerber for such an eye-opening experience, and a viable blueprint.  I'm looking forward to the journey!
B000ETQRCM|5.0|It came in the mail today... always happy with the early arrival of a highly anticipated album.... <br /> <br />Opening the \\"Ten Club\\" package, I tried to suppress my concern in the choice of the album cover; however still excited to see it in the flesh (note= this is what I love about a real album. Touch, feel, smell taste-- in addition to the sound. I just haven't had a digital experience on any level like opening a real physical album - I'm open for any arguments though). It's a unique blue fade cover over a split open avocado. What gives? I still have not gotten the artistic point of this giant green-filled nut, but maybe it will hit me over the next few days. Also, I'm not quite sure of the point of the self-titled album title, \\"Pearl Jam\\". I guess the Beatles did this a few years into their career with the white album, but this isn't the Beatles. Only PJ. Apparently, the boys, I guess wanted to get back to their roots. Thus the simple, self titled title. The White album was the beginning of the end of the Beatles. Hopefully not PJ. We shall see. Maybe we can call it the \\"blue album\\", or the \\"avocado album.\\"  <br /> <br />Inside the album... typical PJ type-font for the lyrics and the standard hand-written EV style for the song titles and the song-writing credits... <br /> <br />The artwork is very dark... think: bald man meets CG drawn puzzle pieces in a dark semi-bloody scene from \\"Dawn of the Dead\\". The only discernable photo of the band is on the CD slip case (Oh, dig the packaging... very similar to the David Gilmour \\"On and Island\\" album; just with the slip holder instead of the rubber center holder- I love this type of booklet-album). The last photo is basically the heads of the band members... kind of creepy I guess... Its okay, I really am a bit more partial to their \\"No Code\\" picture collage. One of the top on the album. Love Eddies lyrics. <br /> <br />Comatose - Totally Guitar driven, yelled chorus, reminds me of spin the black circle ... \\"Feel it rising\\" Yea keep it rocking <br /> <br />Severed Hand- Reverse guitar on intro and goes into Matts tom drum workings. Then it starts to sound like the other three songs riff-driven rocking out Chorus has a nice decent progression. Arcade sounding guitar comes out during the second verses. It gets a little annoying after it comes in again. Great outro guitar solo!!! All over the place. <br /> <br />Marker in the Sand - More guitar riff over Matts Tom-hi-hat jam. Now you got both sides claiming killing in Gods name; but God is no-where to be found, conveniently. More great lyrics Eddie is on top of it, as always. I can hear the end of this jamming out live. It sounds very Who-ish at the end (this is going to be a common theme). Finally hear some Boomer organ at the end. <br /> <br />Parachutes- One of the few acoustic songs on the albums. Simple groove. Love the chords in the chorus, especially when Eddie hits high One of my favs right now. <br /> <br />Unemployable - Reminds me of a Sheryl Crow song maybe just the way eddie sings the verses. I cant pick the song, but Bret, youll know what Im talking about. This one just doesnt do anything for me. Well, the Oh-oh-ohs at the end are really catchy. Other than that to me, it is a B-side. <br /> <br />Big Wave - Vitalogy groove fun song. Just not crazy crazy about it.... <br /> <br />Gone - Acoustic guitar opening the song, nice ebow brings it into Eddies verse. Good organ runs. More bulls eye lyrics even talking about gas prices and the tough cost of driving (in more than one meaning) <br /> <br />Wasted Reprise - short chorus over organ re-run of Life-Wasted. I hope they do this in concert prior to performing life wasted. Wound be a nice build-up <br /> <br />Army Reserve - probably the most groove-downbeat song on the album. I like the tingle of the echo swelled guitar runs during all of the song. <br /> <br />Come Back- This one is going to be a great concert sing-along. Eddie, you got a whole lot of soul on that chorus! This is the one soul-song of the album!!! Mike, beautiful solo at the end!!!! (I think that is you Mike, maybe Stone. Isnt Mike usually left speaker?) This song is amazing. Best song on the album hands down.  <br /> <br />Inside Job - Very pretty Piano riff and Jeffs bass line over simply acoustic strum. Ebow feedback guitar over that. I used to try to kill love. These are maybe Eddies best lyrics, really great lyrics. Every listen I get into it more. Song builds up into a three-chord bounce before hitting the chorus (more Who trademark guitar) and then going into the traditional guitar riff foundation that makes this album and PJ. 2nd Best song on the album, hands-down.  <br /> <br />Album ends with a strange echo chimmy Edge guitar riff coming end and going out Not anything special <br /> <br />Im usually not one for orders of songs, but this is how I feel right now: <br /> <br />1. Come Back <br />2. Inside Job <br />3. Gone <br />4. Parachutes <br />5. World Wide Suicide <br />6. Life Wasted / Wasted Reprise <br />7. Army Reserve <br />8. Severed Hand <br />9. Marker in the Sand <br />10. Comatose <br />11. Big Wave <br />12. Unemployable <br /> <br />Final thoughts - Great PJ album. I havent really hitched instantly onto any PJ album since Vitalogy, but this is going to grow on me nicely The acoustic / mellow songs are usually the top on my list on any PJ album (Daughter / Soon Forget / Elderly Woman / Thumbing / Parting Ways / All Those Yesterdays)... This album doesnt have anything seriously acoustic; guess the boys wanted to rock... but they rock out very nicely Keep on rocking, you do it so well Only criticism I might have at this point is your choice of an avocado as the album cover. I dub thee king of avocado rock! Cant wait to see you live until next time... <br /> <br />Ohh... almost forgot... B000EULJLU|5.0|I'll preface this review by noting that I was one of the few fans who knew about and had access to the leaked album, but opted to wait for the release.  OK, maybe not quite--I was able to secure the album from a local retailer a day early.  I'm glad I waited, because had I not, I might have been more likely to go in for the decoy album theory circulating on many Tool discussion boards, and would not have taken the time to appreciate the album I had in my hands.   <br /> <br />This is not to say that I wouldn't prefer having two Tool albums to one any less than the next guy.  But I think that a lot of folks out there did themselves and the band a disservice by immediately writing off _10,000 Days_ as some kind of hoax.  I've read a great deal of commentary about the record in the weeks leading up to the release, and I must say that now, having heard the album, I am shocked that so many who identify as fans of this band ignored the central tenet of any new Tool album:  give it time.   <br /> <br />I still remember the first time I heard the song \\"Third Eye\\" from 1996's _Aenima_.  I didn't understand what I was hearing, and it made me uncomfortable.  Some of the riffs sounded familiar, there were long instrumental breaks with little discernable function, the vocals were at times far back in the mix and hard to decipher...in short, most of the complaints so many bloggers have been making about _10,000 Days_, I could have made about \\"Third Eye\\" (and much of the rest of _Aenima_) after a cursory first listen.  But luckily for everyone, I didn't have access to a computer with enough memory to run much more than simple word processing software, and I certainly didn't have high-speed internet access, so I couldn't leap right to the keyboard to express my consternation and disappointment.  If I had, I'd have ended up dreadfully embarrassed a few days and many listens later when I discovered I loved every difficult, meandering second of the record. <br /> <br />Now, I'm not one of those reviewers who believes that anyone who doesn't immediately love this album \\"just doesn't get it.\\"  It is possible, presumably, that one could listen to _10,000 Days_, fully digest all of its complexity, and still hate it.  After all, not everyone in the world loves Tool, and while some of these people assuredly do not get it, some of them also just don't care for the band's style or the band members' quirky personalities and beliefs (Tool have beliefs?! *gasp*).  That's OK. <br /> <br />It could also be that one fully comprehends the progression of the band on _10,000 Days_, yet doesn't think the band had any business in going to this new place and is not interested in following them there.  For instance, there are probably people out there who wish the band had put out four more records just like _Opiate_.  And that's OK too.   <br /> <br />I don't think it makes any sense for me, or anyone else, to try to persuade someone who doesn't like the new album for one of those reasons.  I only wish to quibble with those who identify as Tool fans and who say they embrace the progressive, transformative qualities of the band's music while bashing _10,000 Days_ as the embodiment of neither.   <br /> <br />It is frankly very sad to read the comments from fans who are so quick to dismiss the album because they think it is A) too derivative, or B) Maynard's vocals aren't loud enough, or C) they think the segues are merely \\"filler,\\" or D) they don't like the lyrical subject matter of the album.  Since so many seem to hold _Aenima_ up as the standard by which Tool will be forever judged, many of these criticisms strike me as particularly odd.  A quick, by no means comprehensive refutation of each: <br /> <br />A) The band have always been consciously self-referential--see the quiet section of \\"Third Eye\\" and tell me the guitar riff doesn't remind you of \\"Sober.\\"   <br /> <br />B) Throughout _Aenima_, the vocals are heavily processed and employed as another instrument--see the intro to \\"Eulogy.\\"   <br /> <br />C) _Aenima_ has more segues than _10,000 Days_, and guess what--in both cases, they are meant to enhance the overall mood of the record.  Since when do open-minded music fans disregard anything without a steady drum beat or vocal melody as \\"filler\\"?  (Incidentally, \\"Lost Keys\\" and \\"Intension\\" are two of my favorite tracks on the record). <br /> <br />D) This is my favorite.  You take offense to Tool suddenly \\"telling you what to believe?\\"  Here's news, everyone:  the oft-exalted liner notes from _Aenima_ (without even beginning to mention the lyrics) are _extremely_ didactic.  \\"Believe in nothing\\"?  Isn't that a command?   <br /> <br />My hunch is that many bloggers feel threatened by the lyrics on _10,000 Days_ because they suddenly feel implicated.  It's OK if Maynard sings about rejecting religious dogma or investigating the principles of alchemy, because it allows all of our armchair atheists to rest comfortably in apathetic superiority while mocking the ignorant masses.  But God forbid he talk about politics, because then we have to think about the ways we are all complicit in our respective governments' horrific actions.  No, it's much easier to never take a stand on anything important--give us the safety of our keyboards and Tool message boards.  Vicariously we live while the whole world dies. <br /> <br />One caveat:  I've only listened to the album in full twice, and so by no means do I claim to fully understand everything the band are throwing at us.  During my first listens of any album, I consciously avoid analyzing structure in favor of appreciating the raw aural experience.  I'm not going to lecture anyone on the time signatures at use here, or the great fill Danny does at X time in Y song, or the subtleties of Maynard's harmonies in song Z. <br /> <br />What I can say is that my second listen, while still difficult, was much more rewarding than the first, and I expect my appreciation to grow exponentially withsubsequent listens.  The record is dense, and probably not what you were expecting, but the process of discovery is immensely gratifying (and not the sort of thing you're likely to get with many other bands).  I encourage everyone who buys this album to do what they have done with every Tool album, and should do with every album, period:  give it time. <br /> <br />Oh, and then go do something productive besides lurking on Internet message boards.
B000GFLKF8|4.0|INSIDE MAN opens with a bank robber, Dalton Russell (Clive Owen) explaining that he has just robbed a bank. The who, what, when, where, and why are questions that everyone already knows the answers to. What people don't know is the how. The movie then illustrates just how Russell was able to complete his master heist.<br /><br />Russell and his gang begin their caper by entering a premier bank in New York posing as painters. They shine lights at the cameras, lock the doors, reveal their weapons, and announce that a robbery is in progress. Confusion mounts as the robbers dress those in the bank in identical costumes. Along the way, a game of wits is played between Russell and Det. Keith Frazier (Denzel Washington). Frazier knows Russell is up to something but he just can't figure out what. Hired into the game by the owner of the bank, Arthur Case (Christopher Plummer), is independent &#34;fixer&#34; Madeline White (Jodie Foster). White's presence seems unnecessary for most of the movie, but she adds a wild card into the whole scenario that cannot be ignored. The fun part is trying to figure out just how it's all going to play out in the end and how Russell is able to escape with a fortune, but no stolen money and without being caught.<br /><br />INSIDE MAN has a great cast with some fabulous acting. Washington, Foster, and Plummer are magnificent as always, but stronger performances are given by some of the film's supporting actors, particularly Chiwetel Ejiofor as Frazier's assistant Bill Mitchell and Waris Ahluwalia as Vikram Walia, a Sikh hostage who when released from the bank is at first thought to be a terrorist.<br /><br />For a heist picture, INSIDE MAN moves rather slowly. Yet, at the slower pace the movie never really drags. Also, scattered throughout the movie are moments of social commentary-such as when Russell speaks with a young boy in the bank during the heist about the hand held video game he is playing. Beside the commentary, these moments also provide greater depth to the characters we see on the screen.<br /><br />Overall, INSIDE MAN is an enjoyable heist picture. It's a movie that a wide audience can relate to. It isn't Spike Lee's best picture, but it is his most commercial.ide greater depth to the characters we see on the screen.<br /><br />Overall, INSIDE MAN is an enjoyable heist picture. It's a movie that a wide audience can relate to. It isn't Spike Lee's best picture, but it is his most commercial.
B000EULJLU|5.0|As everyone knows, this album was leaked about two weeks ago.  I, like most others, am a simple, simple human, and thus lacked the fortitude to wait the extra two weeks. <br /> <br />But I made up for it by buying two copies of this amazing production. <br /> <br />Tool fans often get ragged on for being very high-strung and arrogant about being a Tool fan.  There is some truth to this.   <br /> <br />But after opening this CD package up and looking at the art, as well as digesting the astonishing production and technique that this band exhibits, and reeling over the emotional landscape they cover, I can honestly say that there has not been an album like this ever made,  which ever way you look at it. <br /> <br />Tool is a constantly innovative and progressive band; none of their CDs sound alike.  This CD almost seeks to violate every assumption someone has about what makes something \\"epic\\".  The two-parter about Maynard's mother occurs on tracks 3 and 4, and the end of the album is a 5 minute non-song.   <br /> <br />But once you really sit down and listen to it, this album is quite simply Tool singing the blues.  I can picture the singer sitting on a Mississippi bayou writing the lyrics to this.  There are so many allusions to Christian mythology in an attempt to convey very simple human emotions.  The songs about drug use in the middle of the album seem to suggest the way we deal with tragedy and loss. <br /> <br />This is NOT Lateralus, both sonically and thematically.  The band shows such a progressive landscape, and whereas Lateralus emphasized Danny drums and Maynard's vocal, 10,000 Days showcases Adam's guitar and Justin's unbelievable bass playing.  He really has to be heard to be believed; get a good sound system for this CD. <br /> <br />Thematically, this album goes in the opposite direction.  Where Lateralus ended celebrating the potential unity of humanity (\\"we are all one mind\\"), this album ends with a song about humanity's dark side, aptly titled \\"Right in Two\\". <br /> <br />If the artistic direction for the CD package doesn't win an award, then there is no taste left in the music industry.  I will simply say that Alex Gray and Tool have changed the way I'll evaluate \\"liner notes\\" completely. <br /> <br />The entire spectacle of this CD has completely affirmed my \\"arrogance\\" at being a Tool fan, and I'm proud to say it!  Go buy this CD.  Now.  You will not f*cking regret it.

Whitneys positively exquisite and exhilirating vocal delivery was astoundingly powerful, much in the shadow of the great, Aretha Franklin. Despite its glorious content, You Give Good Love bombed on the U.S charts and was therefore not even issued in the U.K through lack of interest.  <br /> <br />The slice of disco-pop in distinctly 80's style was the angelic, How Will I Know, a rather sappy and girly tune that hardly had the credibility of the previous single, but emerged as a winner where it topped the U.S charts, whilst storming its way into the U.K Top 10 charts. How Will I Know was produced by Narada Michael Walden who would go on to produce more of her work on future albums.  <br /> <br />Thinking About You was an electric affair with its startling electro-pop orchestrations whilst Whitneys vocal delivery is highly dynamic. More jamming pop follows with the upbeat, Someone For Me, where her rocketing vocal delivery is once again astoundingly strong.  <br /> <br />The genius Michael Masser who had produced countless soul classics with divine soul diva, Diana Ross, was involved in most of the project and worked his magic again with this breathtaking singer. The ballad, Saving All My Love For You is so uplifting and timeless. The full force of her vocal techniques floods out on this tear-jerker of a classic. Her delivery on here is almost mesmerising.  <br /> <br />She duets with Jermaine Jackson on the sugary, Nobody Loves Me Like You Do. There is a nice range of harmonies between these two fabulous singers and even a slight air of sexual chemistry between the two sizzles through. All At Once is another sweeping ballad where she is joined by a gospel backing choir on the exalting chrous. All At Once became another huge International hit to her credit.  <br /> <br />Theres another duet with Jermaine Jackson included with the exotic, late night R&B number, Take Good Care Of My Heart where their vocals are propelled into full effect and both sound equally as magnificent as one another. A timeless collaboration though failed to hit the U.S top 40 charts when released as a single there.  <br /> <br />Another one of Whitneys most definitive classics follows with her fantastic cover of The Greatest Love Of All where her wide range of spectacular abilities is displayed yet again.  <br /> <br />Hold Me is a sickly romantic ballad on which she duets with soul crooner, Teddy Pendergrass. Despite the overly syrupy content the track is actually exhilirating on just hearing these two fine singers like captured on record together. Always makes for a dynamic combination.  <br /> <br />This album is actually quite remarkable for a debut. Consistent, solid and high quality work from one of the greatest singers of our era, it is an indeed timeless classic and stands as some of her most memroable work.  <br /> <br />

B000001FT2|5.0|Following the excellent Warm Leatherette (1980) album, her debut on the Island Records label which saw her rewarded with more commercial acceptance, the outrageous and off-the-wall diva, Grace Jones returned to the recording studios in early 1981 for the unforgetable Nightclubbing project.  <br /> <br />Grace Jones second album on Island Records is possibly the greatest of her considerably short recording career and captured Jones at her artistic peak. It features a series of remarkable recordings, encapsulating a multitude of styles such as New Wave, Reggae, Funk, Jazz and Soul. She was again aided by the fabulous production skills of those reggae kings, Sly Dunbar and Robbie Shakespeare.  <br /> <br />Nightclubbing (1981)begins with the curiously compelling, Walking In The Rain, which sets a dark, atmospheric tone for the duration of the project. The hypnotic, trancey arrangements are ignited by a compelling performance from Jones who literally inteprets the lyrics into an interesting spoken interlude. This is one of her most bizarre and off the wall recordings, yet there is something fascinating about this recording despite its blatant weirdness.  <br /> <br />Jones then delivers what's possibly her very, very best recording ever - Pull Up To The Bumper. This funk-driven track, complete with spiralling rythms, is totally infectious. The lyrics are scattered with double entendres . In the U.S, Pull Up To The Bumper catapulted to No.5 on the Black music singles whilst shooting to No.2 on the Club Play listings. In the U.K Pull Up To The Bumper fell just outisde the top 50 charts though on its re-issue in 1986 zoomed in at No.12.  <br /> <br />Her cover of Bill Withers ,Use Me has a striking musical arrangement and holds a surprisingly strong and assertive vocal performance from Grace. Her unique version of Iggy Pop's Nightclubbing is a total contrast to the original, flowing with strange, synchronized sounds that was way ahead of its time.  <br /> <br />The New Wave sounds of Art Groupie is another interesting concoction, but the music steadily steers direction, driving into jazz on the eccentric but undeniably brilliant, I've Seen That Face Before in which Grace delivers both English and French spoken passages.  <br /> <br />The disappointment of the album comes in the lacklustre version of Feel Up - the reason being was that she did a far better version in her A One Man Show (1982).  <br /> <br />However the album soon gets back on track with the stomping rock track, Demolition Man which is ignited by tough, thrashing musical arrangements and a red blooded, ferocious performance from Jones who conveys a lot of spirit and fire.  <br /> <br />The album gradually winds down with a surprise in the jazz-soul number I've Done It Again. This number allows you to appreciate the surprisingly soothing qualities of her voice. Never have I heard her sound so effeminate as she does on this track.  <br /> <br />Nightclubbing is an ESSENTIAL Grace Jones album. It raced to No.9 on the black music album charts, whilst gliding into the U.K and U.S Top 40 album Charts. It was also voted album of the year by New Musical Express magazine.  <br /> <br />Ian Phillips  <br /> <br />June 2006 <br />
