B000BTJDGC|4.0|Looking back into my childhood there were certain films which really scared the living hell out of me. Movies like the Changeling, the Exorcist and even the original House on Haunted Hill gave me the creeps and kept me awake in bed late at night. When you look at those films today they are pretty outdated but still have a place in our hearts. Sadly very few movies today can actually scare me and I know its like that for every long time horror viewer. As we get older we mature as human beings and our childhood fears die out. Thats why as we are older it takes a lot more to even make the hairs on our arms stand up. So we all search for at least one film that will actually hope to scare us like when we were kids. Some people found that in movies like the Ring, the Sixth Sense and heck even White Noise. It all depends on the persons individual tastes and fears. <br /> <br />For me personally the thought of dealing with something you know very little about really gets under my skin. Ghosts, demons and just the thought of supernatural forces really gave me the creeps as a kid (still does today). Today I got the chance to check out The Exorcism of Emily Rose. A film which surrounds the court case of Father Moore, a priest who is accused of negligent homicide after a failed exorcism. Moore has been claimed responsible for the death of a 19 year old woman said to be possessed by demons. In a battle between faith vs. science, Father Moore is determined to tell the truth about what happened to Emily Rose. <br /> <br />I know how commercials today can fool viewers. In this case what you see in the commercials are in this movie, but there is a lot more to it. There is more to the plot and the story rather than just being about a girl under the control of demons. About 60 percent of the film takes place in a court room and the story of Emily Rose is told in flashbacks from different characters. Most of it is focused on story and the possibility of what really happened. As mentioned before its basically a battle between faith and science. It works really well with this film and I enjoyed almost every scene. The court room scenes are actually pretty entertaining because it keeps you thinking. <br /> <br />I was amazed at how this movie gave me the creeps. It goes to show you that you don't need an R rating for a horror/thriller film to be good. This movie has no gore and very little blood, but thats the beauty of it. Its not meant to be that way at all. Instead its main focus is to scare the audience and show just how dangerous supernatural forces can be. I thought it worked very well and it really got to me in parts. The court room scenes and the other flashbacks hype you up for the main exorcism scene which comes later. When it hits it goes out with a bang. The exorcism scenes are really intense. Truthfully my heart was pounding the entire time they showed the main exorcism scene near the middle of the film. Being scared is great and being creeped out is just as fun. <br /> <br />I don't know that much about the events which inspired this movie, but after seeing it I'm very curious and most likely will be doing my own research about the true events. Overall I had a pretty good time watching this movie. It gave me the creeps in some parts and it really had me thinking. The story is good and the court room stuff is very interesting to watch. My best advice is seeing this film with an open mind. The commercials never show any of the court room stuff, but it's there and it's the main focus of the film. The scares are also there and it's not like any of the past demonic/possession films we've seen in the past. This one is pretty different and its blended with the idea of questioning what is really possible.
B000ETQRCM|5.0|I'm a PJ fan who thinks that Binaural and especially Riot Act are good albums - Riot Act mostly succeeds in the curve balls it throws - but I think this CD is as good as Ten, Yield, and Vitalogy. While Ten had more memorable individual songs, the self-titled album is very memorable as a whole. You'll come away thinking, yeah - that rocked! The ballads, which are in the classic rock vein, don't interrupt the momentum. If you're concerned that Pearl Jam is just a poor carbon copy of their past selves, it is a return to basics - but there's somewhat of a '00s touch. I'd rather they didn't go with some of the modern rock sounds of today that I find boring. And I don't think most fans want a lot of experimentation. This is another strong best of 2006 candidate.
B00009UW0N|5.0|I get the same question from a lot of people who ask me, 'What are your favorite horror movies?'. Whenever I answer those questions, the first movie I always bring up is John Carpenter's Halloween, the 1978 cult classic film that revolutionized horror films. With its low budget and uncanny frightening experience, John Carpenter found a way to spread fear across theatre seats with loveable characters, horrifying music and a knife-wielding maniac who stalks and kills babysitters. In the year 1963 on Halloween night, in the town Haddonfield Illinois a 6 year old boy named Michael Myers kills his older sister with a kitchen knife. After the terrible murder Michael went into psychiatric care. 15 years later on the night of October 30, he escapes from the mental hospital and returns to the town of Haddonfield.<br /><br />This is a movie I remember watching a lot when I was a kid. I used to stay up at night with my older cousins and watch this when it was on TV., and trust me it scared the bejesus out of me when I was a child. When I look back at it now, I pretty much changed my reason why I like this movie. Now that I&#8217;m older the scares don&#8217;t get to me, but I am more fascinated with the storyline and plot of the film. That&#8217;s the reason why I love the Halloween films so much. The story is what keeps me going as a fan of this remarkable series.<br /><br />If I can remember correctly, both John Carpenter and Debra Hill shot this movie during spring of 1978, with a low budget of $300,000. Shot in 20 days this low budget movie went on to make millions when it was released. Even to this day with the number of video sales, its still making money. Originally when this film was made, it had no music in it. So John Carpenter spent 3 days and created the films score, which even to this day is still a brilliant piece of art. The biggest thing that makes this movie brilliant is the music. The acting in this movie is great as well, Jamie Lee Curtis makes her first movie role playing the lead babysitter named Laurie Strode. Laurie Strode to me is the nerdy innocent character in the whole movie. Donald Pleasance plays the role of Michael's Doctor, who in fact only had about 5 days of shooting for the movie.<br /><br />Donald's character in the movie is kind of like the hero to this story, destined to get rid of the evil which is spreading across Haddonfield. Brian Andrews plays the role of Tommy Doyle, the frightened little boy who throughout the movie is afraid of \\"the boogeyman\\". Nick Castle plays the role of the infamous Michael Myers who gives a stunning performance with his body language, since of course Michael Myers is an evil character who doesn't speak. The Shape aka Michael Myers is the kind of character who embodies evil itself. Wearing a mask to cover his blank and pale emotionless face.<br /><br />Another thing that I liked about this movie was the fact that its pretty much bloodless. There is no gore in this movie, and there is very little blood actually shown. Which I think is absolutely brilliant. This movie focuses more on scares (which I thought was very successful), rather than trying to make you sick to your stomach. When you watch this movie, you may notice that some parts of this film were pretty much inspired by other films. Carpenter was inspired by none other than Alfred Hitchcock, and he gave this movie that sort of Hitchcock feel to it. Where your main focus is to basically scare the audience not only with the dark look and music, but by also the evil being himself Michael Myers.<br /><br />Also if you didn&#8217;t know, the mask that you see Michael Myers wearing in this movie, is actually a William Shatner Star Trek mask, which was changed and painted white. So you can pretty much say that Captain Kirk is the one that&#8217;s stalking and murdering all these babysitters. With this movie John Carpenter and Debra Hill had found new ways to frighten an audience. John manages to put the audience in the killer's point of view, which was rarely done back in the day. Although the point of view camera shots were done before in horror films, none were ever as good when it came to giving out scares. Oh and I forgot to mention, originally John Carpenter wanted Peter Cushing to play the role of Dr. Loomis, but he turned it down. John then tried to get Christopher Lee to play the role, he turned it down as well.<br /><br />I think that the best scene in this entire movie has to be the ending. The ending to this film pretty much gives you an idea that evil never dies. Just the way it was portrayed near the end of the movie was brilliant. This movie is the slasher film that started it all. With its Hitchcock influence, this movie doesn't focus on gore or any other cheap horror tricks. John Carpenter manages to scare people with an eary musical score, and an evil and emotionless character. He also managed to use the camera to his advantage. Hands down this is one of the greatest horror films of all time. This movie definitely proves that evil never dies.in the killer's point of view, which was rarely done back in the day. Although the point of view camera shots were done before in horror films, none were ever as good when it came to giving out scares. Oh and I forgot to mention, originally John Carpenter wanted Peter Cushing to play the role of Dr. Loomis, but he turned it down. John then tried to get Christopher Lee to play the role, he turned it down as well. <br /> <br />I think that the best scene in this entire movie has to be the ending. The ending to this film pretty much gives you an idea that evil never dies. Just the way it was portrayed near the end of the movie was brilliant. This movie is the slasher film that started it all. With its Hitchcock influence, this movie doesn't focus on gore or any other cheap horror tricks. John Carpenter manages to scare people with an eary musical score, and an evil and emotionless character. He also managed to use the camera to his advantage. Hands down this is one of the greatest horror films of all time. This movie definitely proves that evil never dies.

B000EULJLU|4.0|Back in 1996, I fell in love with Tool's \\"Aenima\\" album. It was the most inspiring and diverse album I had heard since NIN's \\"Downward Spiral.\\" After a 5-year wait, I wasn't sure the next album could measure up...but when \\"Lateralus\\" finally came out, I was pleasantly surprised! The album was almost as good, if not JUST as good as \\"Aenima.\\" So here we are 5 years later again, and yesterday I picked up my copy of the eagerly anticipated \\"10,000 Days.\\" Although I love what the album has to offer, I have to say, it isn't much.<br /><br />On past Tool albums, the CDs contained as much as 13 or 15 tracks, keeping in mind that a small bundle of those are filler tracks. Well, this CD only has 11 tracks, and yet there is just as much filler as the past CDs. (Filler tracks are tracks on the CD that aren't actual songs, but just brief clips of weird sounds to enhance the listening experience.) When I listen to this album, I feel like I'm listening to a very long EP, because really, there's only about 7 or maybe 8 new songs on here.<br /><br />The opening track, \\"Vicarious\\" is the album's first single and is possibly the best song on the album. It's your typical energetic Tool rocker. The following song, \\"Jambi\\" keeps the pace going with more heavy guitar chugging with Maynard's whispering and screaming. But on \\"Wings For Marie\\" and \\"10000 Days\\", things start to slow down. It's not a bad thing, I've always enjoyed Tool's quiet and emotional moments. Both songs are pretty long without much tempo change, but I actually see these 2 tracks as one long song. Things pick back up again with \\"The Pot\\", which begins with some bizarre high-pitched singing from Maynard. But there's some great guitar work going on and it holds up to the album's first 2 songs. Next is \\"Lipan Conjuring\\" which is just a filler track...it's about a minute and a half long of this creepy Indian-like chant. Then \\"Lost Keys\\" starts out like a song, but it's really just an intro into the NEXT song. (Yes, 2 fillers in a row.) \\"Rosetta Stoned\\" is a lengthy epic that explores lots of different emotional areas. It's a good track, but I wouldn't hold it up to tracks 1, 2 and 5. \\"Intension\\" is a very quiet moment, similar to \\"Disposition\\" from the last album. \\"Right In Two\\" is the last SONG on the album, and while it's a good track, it seems less inspired than most of Tool's previous work. Then the album draws to a close with one more filler, \\"Viginti Tres\\", which is just a few minutes of weird noises.<br /><br />As a diehard Tool fan, it hurts to not give this CD 5 stars, but I can't be an easy critic just because I love the band. There's some great new music on here, it's just that after 5 years, you'd think they could offer more music and less filler on here. Also, I've always given Tool a lot of credit for taking major musical steps with each album, but they don't really explore any new territory this time. In fact, pretty much everything on here could pass for \\"Lateralus\\" b-sides. I know it seems like I'm complaining a lot...don't get me wrong, the music that's on here is excellent, I just feel like they could've offered more.<br /><br />I'll close by describing the album's artwork, which is excellent. The packaging is revolutionary. All of the artwork is done by Alex Grey, who I am a huge fan of and he did all the artwork for \\"Lateralus\\" and the images on the Lateralus tour. The booklet contains something I haven't seen in a Tool album in a long time...pictures of the band. The packaging comes with a pair of lenses, and as you look through them at ALL of the pictures and paintings, they appear to be 3-dimensional..) \\"Rosetta Stoned\\" is a lengthy epic that explores lots of different emotional areas. It's a good track, but I wouldn't hold it up to tracks 1, 2 and 5. \\"Intension\\" is a very quiet moment, similar to \\"Disposition\\" from the last album. \\"Right In Two\\" is the last SONG on the album, and while it's a good track, it seems less inspired than most of Tool's previous work. Then the album draws to a close with one more filler, \\"Viginti Tres\\", which is just a few minutes of weird noises. <br />As a diehard Tool fan, it hurts to not give this CD 5 stars, but I can't be an easy critic just because I love the band. There's some great new music on here, it's just that after 5 years, you'd think they could offer more music and less filler on here. Also, I've always given Tool a lot of credit for taking major musical steps with each album, but they don't really explore any new territory this time. In fact, pretty much everything on here could pass for \\"Lateralus\\" b-sides. I know it seems like I'm complaining a lot...don't get me wrong, the music that's on here is excellent, I just feel like they could've offered more. <br />I'll close by describing the album's artwork, which is excellent. The packaging is revolutionary. All of the artwork is done by Alex Grey, who I am a huge fan of and he did all the artwork for \\"Lateralus\\" and the images on the Lateralus tour. The booklet contains something I haven't seen in a Tool album in a long time...pictures of the band. The packaging comes with a pair of lenses, and as you look through them at ALL of the pictures and paintings, they appear to be 3-dimensional.

B000BMSTMS|4.0|It's been about 5 months since \\"See You On The Other Side\\" was released. I picked it up on release day, but I've waited a while to let the album sink in and grow on me, as it has to do. Certain Korn CDs like \\"Issues\\" and \\"Take A Look In The Mirror\\" had everything I wanted in a Korn album, and I loved them instantly. But with albums like \\"Untouchables\\" and this one, I'd listen to it the first couple of times and say, \\"Huh?\\" Although \\"Untouchables\\" was odd to me at first, once I became familiar with the songs I grew to love the album. I figured that would be the case with this album as well, and it was.<br /><br />Ever since \\"Follow The Leader\\" came out, Korn has taken some very big musical steps with each album. On this album, the group's sound has evolved more than ever before. The pop producers known as The Matrix did not at all add a mainstream sound to Korn, they simply expanded their already existing sound. Each specific member of the band still seems to have his own usual style...the guitar, bass, drums and vocals are all similar to the past albums, and the absense of longtime member Head has not seemed to directly affect the writing. What has changed though, is this new wall of sound built up around their usual style. All the songs have lots of digital effects and synthesizers in them. I know that may upset some people, but I've always encouraged artists to expand their sound. If I had to pick an album that this one most resembles, I'd say \\"Untouchables\\" because of Jon Davis' singing style and the synth stuff.<br /><br />The album's first track and first single, \\"Twisted Transistor\\", did not have to grow on me at all. The first time I heard it, I couldn't help but dance inside my head it's heavy groove. \\"Politics\\" has guitar that sounds more like traditional modern metal, and the verse sounds kinda bizarre at first, but the chorus is really catchy and you'll soon be singing along with it. \\"Throw Me Away\\" features lots of digital effects and industrial drums, infact musically it sounds like Nine Inch Nails most of the time. \\"Love Song\\" is one of my favorites, just because it so heavy and slow at the same time...it's a really angsty tune. \\"Coming Undone\\" has a We-Will-Rock-You drum beat, and although it's a pretty good song, it wouldn't have been my pick as the next single. \\"Getting Off\\" is a really heavy one with a great chorus that rocks out. \\"Liar\\" has potential to be the next single, and has already been deemed one of the best tracks by fans and critics alike. The album closes with \\"Tearjerker,\\" and it's the first time in Korn's 12 years to do a slow, quiet song. The song isn't as sad as much as it is creepy, infact it would've made a good song to play during the credits of the movie \\"Silent Hill.\\" I love this song just because of it's diversity and desperate sound.<br /><br />If you have an open mind towards experimental metal, give this album a listen. I like the album a lot, but I admit that it's not as good as most of their past efforts...but judge for yourself.cally it sounds like Nine Inch Nails most of the time. \\"Love Song\\" is one of my favorites, just because it so heavy and slow at the same time...it's a really angsty tune. \\"Coming Undone\\" has a We-Will-Rock-You drum beat, and although it's a pretty good song, it wouldn't have been my pick as the next single. \\"Getting Off\\" is a really heavy one with a great chorus that rocks out. \\"Liar\\" has potential to be the next single, and has already been deemed one of the best tracks by fans and critics alike. The album closes with \\"Tearjerker,\\" and it's the first time in Korn's 12 years to do a slow, quiet song. The song isn't as sad as much as it is creepy, infact it would've made a good song to play during the credits of the movie \\"Silent Hill.\\" I love this song just because of it's diversity and desperate sound. <br />If you have an open mind towards experimental metal, give this album a listen. I like the album a lot, but I admit that it's not as good as most of their past efforts...but judge for yourself.
B0000DJZA5|4.0|As a long-time(1964) Beatles fan and record collector, I never tire of hearing the truly fab Four in all their incarnations. This 'Let It Be' album re-release provides a fresh look at its creators' song-making process, songs which still sound beautiful and vital after all these years...Although the between-track lighthearted patter heard on the original album is enjoyable, the payoff here is a chance to hear \\"new\\" alternate versions. Music is a subjective thing, and people have differing opinions, but for the record, to *these* ears, John's \\"Across The Universe\\" sounds like it's finally gotten the sweet treatment it deserves...McCartney's immortal \\"Long and Winding Road\\" is presented in a completely different take - Viva la difference!...I have a fondness for George's charming acoustic blues hommage \\"For You Blue\\" and here it sounds clearer and crisper than the original album...Last but not least, the title song \\"Let It Be\\" comes off shining and improved in every way, with one of Paul's best vocals ever - and that's saying a lot!...I'm just happy to have The Beatles!

B000EULJLU|4.0|When I first listened to AENIMA, I loved it. When I first listened to LATERALUS, I loved it so Tool has been one of my favorite bands for many years. However 10,000 DAYS, unfortunately, did not do the same for me. Sure, it is an excellent album and much better than what most bands put out today, but it just lacked the power that their previous 2 albums had. One of my biggest complaints with this album is how Maynard's vocals are not spotlighted. The main thing I always loved about Tool was Maynard's incredible vocals. I am not one of these people that listens to Tool so it can take me to a 'dreamscape realm' or something. I don't like them for that reason at all, so having people say \\"listen to it the whole way through many times\\" does not work for me. I don't believe I should have to force myself to like something if I don't like it straight off from the first listen. I have never liked Tool for the lyrics either, so I don't care what Maynard is saying, I just want to hear his voice shine and overpower the other instruments like in past albums (songs like \\"Jimmy\\" and \\"Schism\\" for example both have parts where I get chills hearing Maynard's voice exploding and overpowering the other instruments. The closest this album has to that is the very ending of \\"Vicarious\\" and \\"Right In Two\\" but they still don't deliver the same power vocals that I was hoping for). I really also think it is a shame that Tool uses all of these stupid, pointless filler tracks. They did it on both their previous albums as well, but at least they usually led into other songs, whereas 2 of them on here are entirely pointless and used up space that could have been used for another song (which, after 5 years on each cd, there should be NO sound effects tracks on any of their cds). Another huge tragedy to this album is the song \\"Rosetta Stoned\\". The music on this song was superb, but the vocals are beyond pathetic. I understand he is supposed to sound like a mental patient, but I would have MUCH rather heard him sing like normal through this song, because it certainly had potential to be an amazing song. The vocals destroyed it though. Again, Maynard has an incredible voice and so I don't want to hear him always distorting it and making it sound like he is singing into a child's toy walkie talkie. The ONLY part that saves this song from being complete garbage is between 8:38 - 9:15 in the song where he sings normal. That part of the song sounds brilliant, but it is not enough to rescue the rest of the song. My final complaint (and apparently a first) is the album packaging. Sure, the case and artwork looks neat when you use the sterepscopic lenses, but I would have much rather had it in a normal jewel case. First of all, my copy has the booklet glued in it crooked, so everytime I close the case, one corner of the booklet gets bent backwards. The second complaint is that the pouch the cd goes into scratches the cd. After only taking it out 3 times, I am seeing scratches on the bottom of the cd, whereas if it was secured in a plastic case then it would not have scratched so easily. And finally, the case is too big to fit anywhere in or on my CD shelf where I keep all of my other albums. With all of that being said, the album is still good. The songs where Maynard actually sings (with the exception of \\"Rosetta Stoned\\" and \\"Intension\\") are really good. My favorite songs were \\"Right In Two\\", \\"Vicarious\\" and \\"10,000 Days (Wings Part 2)\\". I also have to say that this album is far better than the latest release from A Perfect Circle called EMOTIVE (where only the songs \\"Passive\\" and \\"What's Going On\\" were worth listening to). Also I like 10,000 DAYS much more than both OPIATE EP and UNDERTOW. But overall, it is my 3rd favorite Tool album. I hope the next album will not put Maynard to the back of the mix like this one did and I also hope it won't be another 5 years until the next Tool album comes out, because 10,000 DAYS will certainly not keep me occupied that long, whereas AENIMA and LATERALUS both did. Hopefully it will just sound more like those two as well. I'd rather have too much of a good thing than not enough. Nonetheless, I will still be listening to this album for quite some time to come.ereas AENIMA and LATERALUS both did. Hopefully it will just sound more like those two as well. B0006VYG62|5.0|I first read this book when I was 12, and to my English teacher's horror: I received the question \\"Does your mother know you're reading that!?\\" to which I had the all-too-smug pleasure of being able to honestly reply that \\"Yes, she does, as she is the one who suggested it.\\"<br /><br />The Bell Jar is just incredible, hands down.  I am not the kind of reader who regards it as a sort of proto-feminist canon, instead, I try to limit myself to taking it in through its most legitimate, face-value feeling.  There is a \\"realness\\" to it that is just too good.<br /><br />As poor a context for crediting it with anything positive as it is, it was my first literary introduction to New York City.  There are scenes in it that, even now- years later, stand out so clearly in my mind: when she's walking down the street in the midle of the night, drunk out of her mind, and yet somehow lucid enough to find her way home- tracing her hand along the sides of buildings all the way; or the time she stands outside, stories and stories up in the building she's staying in, and proceeds to throw all her clothes out the window, one by one, floating away in the New York midnight breeze.<br /><br />There is a numbness to the story that trudges along like a silent locomotive: you know the tracks are out ahead and the crash is imminent, you just don't know how, or when, or where, or just how bad it will be.  And it is bad, it is really bad, but that's also why it's so good.  Not to say that tragedy is a hallmark of literary worth, but the tragedy \\"works\\" here because it is just simply too real.<br /><br />As other reviewers have noted, it is a little disturbing that it ends well, when Plath, herself did not.  Yet, in the end, maybe that is the best irony of it?  Regardless, it's one of my favorite books.

B00004XONN|5.0|I love this album: it's incredible.  I first heard it at a very impressionable age in high school.  I grew up in the mid west; it was in the middle of winter; there was snow on the ground; everything was bleak, etc.  I think that, in at least some ways, is the perfect context to take in Kid A: intense adolescent sexual and rebelious angst, coupled with that certain post-industrial alienation of all midwestern cities in the winter: a feeling and a quality I like to swear nowhere else has (though I know I'm wrong).<br /><br />Kid A is not the first Radiohead album you would ideally listen to.  The best way to get into Radiohead is to move chronologically; but of course I didn't.  It is not Ok Computer, even though it is more similar to it than the other previous albums.  It is less accessible: you don't hear the first \\"conventional\\" song until the fourth track, albeit it is entirely worth it to play through to that point as the song is \\"How to Disappear Completely\\" which is just incredible.<br /><br />However, I like what Wikipedia currently has to say on criticism of the album, as is excerpted from, bellow:<br /><br />\\"Finally, Kid A attracted another sort of criticism: that it wasn't as radical as advertised. Canadian post-rock collective Godspeed You Black Emperor! took issue with Radiohead's nonconformist stance given their major label backing, while underground electronic hero Aphex Twin, himself an influence on Kid A, didn't get the big deal. People who had been listening to less commercial forms of music for ages didn't like the way Radiohead had \\"co-opted\\" them, and although always giving credit to their influences, was now being given all the credit themselves in reviews by a musically ignorant or closed minded mainstream media. Indie rock critics in 2000 and 2001 would often cite some lesser known album that was similar to what Radiohead was doing but supposedly much more interesting, Hood's Cold House for example. These views, however, reflected the distinct minority of people who had actually heard music further off the radar than Radiohead.\\"<br /><br />Whoever wrote this makes a really good point that this was not the epitome, or the \\"ultimate\\" in this style of music at the time of 2000, and that Radiohead, in some ways, is more of a quasi-experimental art rock mainstream to lesser-knowns.  I think that's a valid point.  Go check out the rest of the Wikipedia review if you're looking for a really sound, well-informed critique.<br /><br />Regardless, this is still an amazing album.  It is extremely atmospheric and, taken as a whole, feels very artistic- whatever that even means.  I love Kid A.inct minority of people who had actually heard music further off the radar than Radiohead.\\"    <br /> <br />Whoever wrote this makes a really good point that this was not the epitome, or the \\"ultimate\\" in this style of music at the time of 2000, and that Radiohead, in some ways, is more of a quasi-experimental art rock mainstream to lesser-knowns. It is extremely atmospheric and, taken as a whole, feels very artistic- whatever that even means.  I love Kid A.   <br /> <br />

B000ETQRCM|5.0|Don't be fooled by 0-to-1-stars reviews.  Most folks who give this album such a low grade do so just because Pearl Jam 'is not what they used to be in the glorious times of Ten and Vs.'; or because Pearl Jam 'is boring and doesn't rock by today's standards'; or because 'between Binaural, Riot Act and PJ/Avocado there is no difference'. <br /> <br />All these arguments are misleading.  What is the problem if PJ is not the same as Ten or Versus? I don't think many music bands around do the same stuff after 15 years... The musical and lyrical concerns of the band cannot be the same.  The listeners (us) are not the same either.  When I became a Pearl Jam's fan in the 1990s I cared about them for many reasons that are already over.  I still enjoy the older songs, and I do think they still are good music, but I don't judge Pearl Jam's work today by the standards I had then.  I judge them according to my expectations in 2006:  Wonderful, pure rock music, with solid guitars, some interesting lyrics, great drums, etc.   <br /> <br />PJ's latest album, \\"Pearl Jam\\" has great music and is, indeed, a 'must' for fans, and a 'you-should-give-it-a-try'for non-fans who want to listen to good rock n' roll.  It compares favorably to recent works because it is a more coherent album, one that you can listen continuously without skipping songs.  I don't care whether it has 'another Light Years' or 'another Corduroy'.  It's just what it is:  A great album by a great band.

B000EULJLU|5.0|As a long-time Tool fan I was hyping up 10,000 Days and expecting an amazing follow up to Lateralus. I heard that Tool was going back to their Aenima roots which pleased me since that is my favorite album by any band. I was mistaken, though. It is a departure from any record released in their fifteen years together. And it's amazing to boot. <br /> <br />Musically, Tool is tighter than ever. One of the excellent successes of 10,000 Days is the unity between band members. Justin really shows what he can do on the bass this record after being vicariously (heheh) scrutinized by fans on Lateralus. Adam leads the powerhouse of a band with his guitar, which is one of the focuses of the new album. Of course, we received what we all expected from Danny with his demonic drum riffs.  <br /> <br />Maynard delivers as usual with the more variation in his vocals on any album previously released. His voice is as sharp as a knife on the opener, Vicarious, especially when he sings \\"Part vampire/Part warrior/Carnivore and voyeur.\\" In Jambi his voice travels from soothing to chaotic in seven glorious minutes. The Wings (Wings for Marie and 10,000 Days) together highlight the album. In a side we've never seen of Maynard James Keenan in Tool, he sings compassionately and opens up to his fans to reveal personal lyrics. The Wings are epic, clocking together as 17 minutes and 24 seconds, and probably my favorite part of the album. Anyone who doubted Tool's anti-mainstream position on music when looking at the album title \\"10,000 Days\\" will be blown away once they find the meaning to be about MJK's mother, Judith Marie Keenan, who spent 10,000 Days in pain as a paralyzed patient. The Pot shows how much MJK can change his voice in a shocking high pitch beginning. That song is so addictingly fun to listen to and, politcally, the lyrics are superb. The second epic on the disc, Lost Keys/Rosetta Stoned, displays the classic odd Tool and is a direct sequel to Lateralus's Faaip De Oaid. The song, which is an alien experience told from the perspective of a drug-induced man, is one of the craziest songs on 10,000 Days and probably the finest musically--if one can get past the odd lyrics. Intension and Right In Two are calming, beautiful pieces with the former being very similar to Reflection from the previous cd. The outro, Viginti Tres is an odd song which involves the sounds of wings and buzzing with the simple words of \\"The System\\" being said in a demonic voice. <br /> <br />Overall, the cd is a solid release. Tool generally cut back on the filler, aside from Lipan Conjuring (which I really enjoy) and Viginti Tres, and focused more on music this time around. The artwork is as amazing as ever and features my favorite artist, Alex Grey, who did the cd booklet for Lateralus. The stereo-optic glasses are not a gimmick either--Adam Jones has been noting the effect of stereo-optic vision on the human mind for the past few years and hoped that it would provide more interaction between 10,000 Days and the listener. I really enjoy the whole package and though it took me several listens to get into, it is a must buy for any rock fan. <br /> <br />5 stars.

B000ETQRCM|5.0|It's quite possible that Pearl Jam is more revered in retrospect than for their musical offerings from the last 5-6 years. Their name is legendary. And their initial 2-3 albums are considered classics. But what have they done lately that hasn't sounded tired and stale? <br /> <br />Even though I'd been burned by PJ's albums in the past, I took a chance on this new one, simply titled Pearl Jam. <br /> <br />Wow. Am I glad I did. Pearl Jam has been reborn!  <br /> <br />This album sounds fresh, alive and -- dare I say it? -- vital. They retained their trademark garage band sound and Eddie's sometimes mumbly (but powerful) baritone. But there are melodies and hooks on this album that are infectious. And the playing sounds like a Pearl Jam I haven't heard in a long, long time. It's energetic and meaty. <br /> <br />The album kicks off with the guitar-heavy, toe tapping \\"Life Wasted,\\" which sports typical Pearl Jam chord progressions but with more oomph behind them.  <br /> <br />\\"World Wide Suicide,\\" the next track, features a sound and energy reminiscent of anything off Vs. or their debut CD (1993 and 1991, respectively). <br /> <br />\\"Comatose\\" begins with a Tom Petty-like guitar riff and then explodes in Eddie's growling vocal and bashing, punk-like guitars that would make the Sex Pistols proud. <br /> <br />One of my favorite tracks follows \\"Comatose\\": \\"Severed Hand,\\" which begins with swirling, mysterious-sounding backward-played guitar noodlings before turning into another free-for-all garage band extravaganza. <br /> <br />\\"Parachutes,\\" a Beatle-esque song featuring acoustic guitar, a jaunty beat and tight vocal arrangements, is a nice change of pace after so many balls-out tracks. <br /> <br />\\"Unemployable,\\" the next track, is a great riff. Very catchy and upbeat. It reminds me of R.E.M. Very tasty guitar work. <br /> <br />\\"Wasted Reprise\\" is totally captivating. Haunting, even. It's less than a minute long, but there's something about it that I absolutely love. The lyrics are sung with such emotion: \\"I have faced it, a life wasted, I am never going back again.\\" <br /> <br />I can't say enough about this album. It's chock-full of big, BIG guitar riffs, Eddie's over-the-top screaming, crisp production, and heart-on-sleeve lyrics. It's a Pearl Jam you haven't heard in a very long time. <br /> <br />I strongly urge you to buy this new album from Pearl Jam. You won't be sorry.
0440180295|3.0|I have to admit that it is not the same book this thirty-nine-year-old remembers when he read it last at nineteen. Parts of it are brilliant, but I found myself rolling my eyes at the sidetrips to Tralfamadore and his juvenile asides about sex. A review I recently read gets it right:<br /><br />\\"I suppose that once upon a time, this novel must have seemed terribly arch or ironic. B00006AW2M|5.0|TSMR is a one-of-a-kind album in The Rolling Stones catalog.  It is their response to The Beatles' \\"Sgt. Pepper\\".  The album is full of magical and mysterious songs.  The opener, Sing This All Together, sets the quirky pace of the album and the ending of the song leads into the guitar of Citadel, one of the best psychedelic rock songs I've ever heard.  In Another Land is the only song sang by Bill Wyman and the song is pretty good, especially its harpsichord intro.  2000 Man is much like Citadel only a little slower and catchier.  Sing This All Together (See  What Happens) may be the only misstep of the album, it is very long and tedious.  She's A Rainbow is the best on the album and one of the best Stones songs ever.  From the beautiful strings to the Hawaiian-sounding backing vocals, the song is solid from beginning to end.  The Lantern is another good one, it's perhaps the slowest and quietest song on the entire album.  Gomper is East Indian-influenced with its sitar.  The song is great, I especially like its melodic vocals.  2000 Light Years From Home is the second best song with its outer space sound effects.  The last song, On With The Show is funny and cute and ends the album on a lighter note.<br /><br />My advice to any Rolling Stones fan is that you buy this album if you don't already have it, you won't be sorry.
B00003CXXP|4.0|Spielberg is one of my favorite filmmakers both because he knows how to tell a story, takes more risks than other mainstream directors, and always cares about the characters. Often his films are a little too much on the slick side, or as a neighbor kid used to say, \\"There's a whole lot of Hollywood in that movie.\\" A.I. is no different. It walks a line between being bleak and warm, between taking risks and falling back into convention. Parts of it had me in awe and played my emotions, while other parts had me shaking my head in disappointment and irritation.<br /><br />But for all its flaws, there is much to appreciate and think about in this modern take on \\"Pinocchio\\". David, the robot boy who is programmed to \\"love\\" want to be real so that his \\"mother\\" will love him. But what is \\"real\\"? And what is \\"love\\"? Can a machine created by a human be real or even love? Can it be human? Is it alive? What is our responsibility to such a creature? Should we even be dabbling in such things?<br /><br />As maddening and uneven as it can sometimes be (especially the ending), I still highly recommend it.

If doesnt make sense to you then you have made their point.  <br /> <br />Back to the album though,  If this is your first Tool album, dont buy it yet. Buy Lateralus, Salival, or Aenima. B000003TA4|2.0|Nirvana's Nevermind easily ranks as one of the most overrated albums ever made. In any kind of music, period.    Now before you Nirvana fanboys/girls rip me apart, just let me confirm that I don't hate your favorite band (although I do think they are criminally overrated) and I'm not one of those who celebrated Kurt's death. But I do have some major complaints about this album.    Now about Kurt. A genius?! Don't make me bang my head on the keyboard out of laughing. And seriously all you guys who still mourn his death saying \\"KuRt'Z DeTh WaZ LyeK a StAb In MaH HarTT\\" are really starting to get on my nerves. Kurt was nothing special, face it. Why can't you mourn Cliff Burton, Dimebag Darrell, Layne Staley or Chuck Schuldiner? These guys had far more talent than Kurt, and got practically none of the attention they deserved, and today are being forgotten. If Kurt Cobain was a genius the James Hetfield is the Albert Einstein of guitar/vocals, give me a f**king brake. Kurt was easily the most overrated guitarist ever, he never played a half-decent solo and all the songs are structured from 3 powerchords at best. And his vocals were not much better, they were decent at their best and at their worst they were just unbearable. In most of the songs he sings properly in the verse and in the chorus he screams and sounds like a drug abuser. Now I have nothing against screaming in music, but the singer needs to have some abilty to do this. Bruce Dickinson can do it properly, and so Rob Halford, Phil Anselmo and Tom Araya. But Kurt couldn't. However Kurt had some upsides though, his songwriting was quite good, and at least he didn't write lyrics like Korn, Slipknot and Linkin Park who write lyrics all about how depressed they are. The 2 other dudes were also above average. Kris was a decent bassist. Dave Grohl is a great drummer (although he does better stuff today). The album's opener, 'Smells Like Teen Spirit', although extremely overplayed, is probably the best song on the album, although the chorus sucks (due to Kurt's screaming) the verse is great and the basslines and drum beats are actually good. 'Come As You Are' is decent, 'Lithium' is pretty bland. Other than that, this album is boring, uninspired and heavily overrated. And it didn't save rock and roll at any point. The didn't even started grunge (that would be Soundgarden), but I still have doubts that if Pearl Jam's 'Ten' wasn't, but Nevermind was then hair metal was killed.    Nirvana had actually made some really good songs on their swansong In Ultero and few decent on Bleach. These albums have much more well-structured songs, slightly better vocals, although the guitars are still bad. But still Nirvana has nothing on other bands from Seattle such as Queensryche (although they're not grunge), Alice in Chains, Stone Temple Pilots or even Pearl Jam and Soundgarden. All in all, this is not an album that has aged well (despite what many may think) and is easily Nirvana's worst. Judge for yourself.
B000002J6H|5.0|With this self-titled debut solo album, originally released in November of 1970, Stephen Stills finally had an album consisting entirely of his own self-penned material.  However, don't let that, or the fact that Stephen is pictured alone on the front cover with an acoustic guitar, fool you--this isn't as close to a traditional singer-songwriter type of album as you may initially speculate.  Stills has an absolute load of guest artists here, not just background vocalists such as David Crosby, Graham Nash, Rita Coolidge, and 'Mama' Cass Elliot, but also Jimi Hendrix (whom Stills commonly refers to as James Marshall Hendrix), Eric Clapton, Booker T. Jones, and Ringo Starr (credited as Richie), and each of these guests truly add to the record as opposed to just being there for namesake.<br /><br />The characteristically ambitious Stills was clearly going for a 'Big Statement' with this record, and although a couple songs do suffer from overproduction, the album is simply brimming with inspiration, soul, and passion, with a unique mixture of different styles to boot.<br /><br />A gospel influence shines through on many of the tracks to great effect.  Stills starts things off with the top 20 US hit \\"Love The One You're With\\", an intoxicatingly joyful feel-good anthem with a sing-along chorus and exciting organ work--a brilliant way to open the album.  Also gems are the stately, slow-paced, super-emotional \\"Church (Part of Someone)\\"; and \\"Sit Yourself Down\\", which starts with a calmly reflective verse and works its way to a rousing chorus.<br /><br />You get a couple of bluesy tracks with the \\"Old Times Good Times\\" and \\"Go Back Home\\" which are sequenced back to back and feature Hendrix and Clapton respectively.  \\"Old Times Good Times\\" is irresistible with its fun lyrics and Jimi's great guitar work.  The nearly 6-minute \\"Go Back Home\\" starts to ramble after a while during the Clapton section, but it's got splendid, Hendrix-inspired wah-wah guitarwork from Stills, and the stripped-down sound on the first half of the track makes for a nice 'breather' in the context of the album.<br /><br />Stills also really shines on a couple of acoustic tunes played and sung entirely by himself.  The restful \\"Do For The Others\\" is a beautiful, pensive ballad with an endlessly hummable melody.  And Stills delivers a riveting performance on \\"Black Queen\\", with Stephen playing absolutely [...] country-blues licks--it was recorded all in one go, with no overdubs.<br /><br />Stills also takes a cue from Brian Wilson with the arresting, lush, vibes-laden orchestrated ballad \\"To A Flame\\" which sounds like it could have fit in on \\"Pet Sounds\\", and yes, that is definitely a compliment.  There's even a hint of progressive rock on \\"Cherokee\\" with its flutes and 7/4 time signature, and Stills' electric sitar work on it adds yet another flavor to the album.<br /><br />Unfortunately, overproduction rears its ugly head on the last two tracks.  The aforementioned \\"Cherokee\\" could have been another great song, but it gets bogged down by the blaring horns (which instantly recall \\"MacArthur Park\\", by the way), although they only crop up occasionally, so the song still ends up being quite solid.  But Stills really gets carried away with egregious overproduction on the closing track \\"We Are Not Helpless\\"--his careful rendering at the beginning of the song is appealing, and had he stripped away the excess it could have been a really nice album closer, but as it is, it's overkill, foreshadowing the cheesy overproduction that mars some of his follow-up album \\"Stephen Stills 2\\".<br /><br />Despite the occasional gripes, Stephen's ambitiousness really served him well here--the variety of music is highly impressive, as are his varied vocal stylings, and the result is a fascinating and often thrilling listening experience  There is simply a load of terrific, passionate music here, enough to make it a definite must-have.he first half of the track makes for a nice 'breather' in the context of the album.    Stills also really shines on a couple of acoustic tunes played and sung entirely by himself.  The restful \\"Do For The Others\\" is a beautiful, pensive ballad with an endlessly hummable melody.  And Stills delivers a riveting performance on \\"Black Queen\\", with Stephen playing absolutely [...] country-blues licks--it was recorded all in one go, with no overdubs.    Stills also takes a cue from Brian Wilson with the arresting, lush, vibes-laden orchestrated ballad \\"To A Flame\\" which sounds like it could have fit in on \\"Pet Sounds\\", and yes, that is definitely a compliment.  There's even a hint of progressive rock on \\"Cherokee\\" with its flutes and 7/4 time signature, and Stills' electric sitar work on it adds yet another flavor to the album.    Unfortunately, overproduction rears its ugly head on the last two tracks.  The aforementioned \\"Cherokee\\" could have been another great song, but it gets bogged down by the blaring horns (which instantly recall \\"MacArthur Park\\", by the way), although they only crop up occasionally, so the song still ends up being quite solid.  But Stills really gets carried away with egregious overproduction on the closing track \\"We Are Not Helpless\\"--his careful rendering at the beginning of the song is appealing, and had he stripped away the excess it could have been a really nice album closer, but as it is, it's overkill, foreshadowing the cheesy overproduction that mars some of his follow-up album \\"Stephen Stills 2\\".    Despite the occasional gripes, Stephen's ambitiousness really served him well here--the variety of music is highly impressive, as are his varied vocal stylings, and the result is a fascinating and often thrilling listening experience  There is simply a load of terrific, passionate music here, enough to make it a definite must-have.

B000E33VWW|5.0|This brutally honest portrait of author Truman Capote, with its stunning photography (by Adam Kimmel) and Academy Award-winning acting, has been one of the most \\"decorated\\" films of 1995.  Philip Seymour Hoffman, Oscar-winner as Best Actor, becomes Capote in this film--small, effete, and vulnerable, but also selfish, petulant, weak, and sometimes cruel.  Catherine Keener, as Harper Lee, Capote's childhood friend, offers a stunning contrast to Hoffman's Capote.  Tall, honest, and committed to keeping Capote focused, she grounds the film, while serving as Capote's research assistant during his investigation of the cold-blooded killings of four members of the Clutter family in Holcomb, Kansas, in 1959.<br /><br />At the opening of the film, the clean, flat plains and unadorned farmhouse belonging to the victims form a visual contrast with Capote's frantic life in New York.  A naive teenager's discovery of the murders, the savagery of the murders, and effects of the murders on the townspeople continue the contrasts between the harsh realities of local life and the esoteric lifestyle of Capote. When Perry Smith (sensitively played by Clifton Collins, Jr.) and Richard Eugene Hickock (Mark Pellegrino) are arrested, and Capote makes contact with Smith, the viewer suddenly sees Capote and Smith as similar--both lonely, sad, a bit shy, and sometimes frightened.  As Perry Smith begins to confide in Capote, the similarities of their backgrounds and dysfunctional families become even more obvious.<br /><br />Exceptionally opportunistic, Capote is also deeply affected by Smith, feeding him when his hunger strike leaves him close to death, but also borrowing Smith's personal journals for his research because \\"I don't want the world to see you as a monster.\\"  Sometimes abandoning Smith and Hickock for months at a time, Capote comes and goes in their lives, leaving Smith desperate at times, and causing Jack Dunphy, Capote's lover, to accuse Capote of using Smith.  As the six years pass between the crime and the publication of In Cold Blood, Capote himself deteriorates from alcohol and drugs as inexorably as Smith and Hickock have done while awaiting execution.<br /><br />The interactions between Hoffman, as Capote, and Collins, as Smith, lead to poignant scenes of great emotion--Capote dissembling when Smith wants to know the name of the book he is writing, Capote refusing to pay a visit to Smith until just before his execution, and Capote crying \\"I did everything I could,\\" when clearly he did not.  Intensely acted, sensitively directly, stunningly photographed, and hauntingly human, this memorable film takes a close, personal look at Capote and the man he fears may be his alter ego.  n  Mary Whipplecrime and the publication of In Cold Blood, Capote himself deteriorates from alcohol and drugs as inexorably as Smith and Hickock have done while awaiting execution. Intensely acted, sensitively directly, stunningly photographed, and hauntingly human, this memorable film takes a close, personal look at Capote and the man he fears may be his alter ego.  n  Mary Whipple

B000EULJLU|3.0|Is it wrong for me to think that what made Tool so great on Undertow and Aenima was the raw emotion on display? The aggression and rage and contempt? Is it wrong for me to wish that they would continue in that vein instead of just spewing out technically proficient but emotionally sterile prog rock-without-the-prog (and often without the rock either) as they did on Lateralus and now on 10,000 Days as well? Is it wrong for me to be sad that apparently Tool are now content to just regurgitate ideas and go through the motions with practically zero creativity? If it's my fault for feeling this way, I apologize.<br /><br />I will admit that I do enjoy 10,000 Days more than Lateralus. But unfortunately I also have to admit that this album feels like a mountain of dead weight compared to the oceans of energy I found in previous albums.

B000EJ9MTW|3.0|A friend of mine sent me a copy of the British release of this album a couple of months ago, and I was eagerly anticipating the opportunity to purchase the US release. While the songs on the American version are the same as the British version (and actually, they included an extra track, \\"Love Train\\") I had to downgrade this from a 4-star to a 3-star album. Why? They messed with the track order! In the original release, the tracks are sequenced this way: <br /> <br />1. Colossal <br />2. Woman <br />3. White Unicorn <br />4. Pyramid <br />5. Mind's Eye <br />6. Joker And The Thief <br />7. Dimension <br />8. Where Eagles Have Been <br />9. Apple Tree <br />10. Tales From The Forest Of Gnomes <br />11. Witchcraft <br />12. Vagabond <br /> <br />I know this probably seems like nitpicking, but sequencing is important, especially in music like this, which strives so hard to achieve a \\"classic rock\\" sound. And, as if messing with the track order wasn't bad enough, they did a terrible job of editing. For instance, at the end of \\"White Unicorn\\" on the US version, you can hear a aplit second of the beginning of \\"Pyramid\\" (which follows directly after it in the British release) before it lurches into \\"Woman.\\" Would it have been so hard, after they decided to mess with the track order for no reason at all, for them to at least EDIT the transitions between the individual tracks so it doesn't sound like a damn mix tape? <br /> <br />I'm not suggesting you purchase the British import version of this cd (especially since it's three times as expensive) but if you happen to see the import version for a price comparable to the American one, buy that instead, and hear a great album they way it was MEANT to be heard.

B000EULJLU|4.0|i've been a tool fan ever since i heard \\"sober\\" about 7 or so years back. since then, i've heard the changes from album to album, never criticized it, and learned to grow with it. i figured, you can't expect a band to put out the same album every time they record something. <br />and tool definitely preaches that idea. <br />before i start into the album, i must first say that tool definitely changed their sound--lateralus was more organic and slower paced than aenima; aenima was more refined and angst driven than undertow; undertow was more melancholy and ambient than the almost-grunge-like opiate. with 10,000 days, they bring a little of everything from their past into the mix. <br />when \\"vicarious\\" starts out, the guitars sound like they could easily be found on lateralus. the song breaks out into a nice mixture of heavy bass lines and clean riffs accentuated by some tight technical drumming, as always to be expected of the great mr. danny carey. as the song, and the album, goes on, the bass lines become more punctuated, and the guitars sometimes seem to support the bass rather than the other way around. with \\"jambi\\", that groove is definitely more apparent. you hear it the whole album through. i won't describe every song in detail, but nearly every song (save a couple fillers) easily sway in and out of ambient, melodic passages and adrenaline filled classic riffing complimented by lyrics that range from somber to animosity-filled to even happiness. <br /> <br />and the lyrics are something to talk about in themselves. in \\"vicarious\\", maynard unleashes some anger about the media, as well as the viewers, for desensitizing violence, only to include hippies and peace activists near the end of the song. his message seems to be don't downplay violence, but dont try to think that there will ever be peace. \\"jambi\\" describes a man with everything who'd trade it all away for one love. \\"wings for marie pt. 1\\" and \\"10,000 days (marie pt. 2)\\" opens up the subject of maynardand religion yet again - this time, talking about heaven and hell in an almost poignant sort of sense - \\"i only pray/heaven knows when/to lift you out/cause 10,000 days in the fire is too long/you're going home\\". the album continues like this, with messages throughout the album. i must say, lyrically (which, for me, has always been a strong point for them), tool have matured. <br /> <br />to sum it up, the album is awesome for most of its run, but at some points can falter. i rate this on the level of lateralus or even opiate, but, in my eyes, cannot reach the epic level of aenima nor the catchy progression of lateralus. still, i'd recommend it for anyone whos not satisfied with your everyday, run-of-the-mill hard rock, and definitely recommend it to any tool fan who enjoyed lateralus as much as aenima and undertow.
B0002IQJUK|5.0|Gavin Degraw's amazing fusion of acoustic pop, alternative rock and soulful blues crooning has an undeniable magnetism that you just can't help but give in to. While some artist of his age keep their audiences on their toes by acting out a lifestlye like that of a Lifetime special that's just so bad you can't help but watch, Gavin's appeal is deeply rooted in talent and his seemingly effortless ability to not only breathe an entirely original style into his own music, but also into even the most classic of classic songs, like that of Marvin Gaye's \\"Let's Get it On.\\"<br /><br />DeGraw's Chariot Stripped album is the pinnacle of the perfect artistic blend of instrumentation, vocality, and raw emotion. The tracks are so clean cut and pure, at times you can actually hear the sound of the piano bench settle underneath Gavin's weight. Nothing has been tainted with soundboard beats, echo chambers, or even the classic wall of sound, and it could be no better.<br /><br />Gavin display's a wide range of ability on the album from his guttural vocal stylings to his strength as both a guitarist and pianist. No two tracks are at all alike, and each has it's own very precise blend and balance of instrumentation. So many artists rely on looping beat tracks, but there is nothing repetitive about this album, or its production.<br /><br />\\"Meaning\\" is a soft ballad with some of the most insightful and honest lyrics I have ever had the pleasure of hearing. With incredible imagery and heart warming depth, this song cant help but make you love love and question what is all about anyway.<br /><br />One of the true treasures of this album is Degraw's immaculate interpretation of the Sam Cooke classic \\"Change is Gonna Come.\\" The vocality on this track is absolutely gorgeous, and shows a whole new side of Degraw's artistic range, passion, and lends even more credence to the 29-year-old's old-soul-crooner status.<br /><br />\\"Chariot\\" has a very complex piano accompaniment and fantastic, gripping lyrics that could speak to the heart of even the most jaded individual, reminding them once again of the magic of all things simplistic, earthly, and heavenly. A reminder of faith and strength of heart, \\"Chariot\\" brings the whole feel of the album home, summing up quite decisively the complexly minimalistic style that is the life and music of Gavin Degraw.<br /><br />Gavin Degraw is, without a doubt, a very powerful force to be reckoned with. His music is timeless and knows no boundaries of age, race, colour or creed. He is, across the board, one of the most talented, dedicated, tenacious, and promising artist of our time.
0790742780|3.0|This is one of the most haunting films I have ever seen. I saw it only once, when it was first released, and I both loved it and hated it, but I can't forget it. It affected me so strongly because I am a middle aged, white, defense engineer, in Los Angeles. Judging by the other reviews, people see different things in it. But to me it was the only film I have ever seen that expresses the frustration of us who grew up in the 50's and 60's in nice clean middle class neighborhoods thinking that someday we would live just like the Cleavers in a beautiful house in a neighborhood with trees and lawns, and then we grow up and get a job and suddenly find ourselves in a congested, smoggy, paved over place like Los Angeles where we are the minority race. Now I know people will immediately think \\"racist!\\" But what I am talking about is just the shock of such a rapid change in society in one generation. I think anyone of any race in any country would feel the same if their country changed so rapidly.<br /><br />The first half of the film was extremely powerful in portraying this frustration. Bill just wants to go home, but the traffic won't move. He abandons his car and starts to walk. Shouldn't a citizen be able to walk safely thru their own town? But it isn't his town anymore, he is an alien in his own city. He walks thru MacArthur Park, remember that song \\"MacArthur Park is melting in the rain\\"? I always thought MacArthur Park must be a beautiful place, but if you go there now you feel like you are in Guatemala, or a drug dealer's convention. And the scene at Bill's mother's house is so true to life. A little old lady who bought her house 40 years ago in a nice middle class neighborhood where the kids could play outside who now finds the neighborhood changed around her and she needs bars on the doors and windows. I see that every day in Los Angeles, old white-haired people adrift in a world they don't understand. So I was very impressed that the makers of this film expressedthis feeling so accurately.<br /><br />But in the last half of the film they seemed to cave-in to political correctness. There seemed to be no blacks in the film at all, even though the hamburger place was supposed to be in South Central LA. It is as if the film makers thought it was OK to stereotype Hispanics and Asians, but they were afraid to offend blacks. This seemed like a cop-out to me.  And the scene with the neo-nazi surplus store owner was very strange. I was expecting them to become allies, but the neo-nazi guy suddenly turns on him, and Bill ends up killing him. It seemed like the film makers were going out of their way to show that Bill was not a racist, he was just mad at society.<br /><br />And the end of the film infuriated me. The whole movie set me up to identify with and feel for Bill, and then the policeman just kills him and acts like \\"ho-hum, just another day on the job.\\"  And his wife (or former wife?) doesn't seem to care at all. So they just seemed to verify Bill's feeling that nobody cared about him or appreciated all the work he had done his whole life. So in a way, I felt betrayed after sitting thru the whole movie. After-all, even though Bill broke some laws, all the violence he did was in self-defense. So I have never seen the film again, and yet I still remember every bit of it, after 13 years, which is not something I can say about most films.

Clocking in at age 47, some may think that at my age, \\"He just doesn't get it.\\" Well, my younger rockers, that may seem like the case, but I'm still not 80 and I'm not dead yet. Than again, Robert Plant hasn't made an album that is even close to his Led Zep days. AC/DC has put out albums for 26 years after Back in Black, and (even with my suspicions about who wrote the lyrics for this classic disc) they haven't excitied me since. You getting the picture? As we get old, do we lose something? Even if you believe this, hear me out...<br /><br />...Hearing the song \\"Woman\\" on the radio sparked my interest in this band, but everytime I've heard the song, all I hear is Jack White of the duo, White Stripes. Don't get me wrong, there are many other tracks on this disc where the vocals sidetrack me. Mostly because the music on many of the songs is so darned, ummm...different. But then again, I've heard this music before. Oh, the beautiful distortion!<br /><br />Sabbath, Uriah Heep, Deep Purple, Blue Cheer, Grand Funk Railroad, and many others (and YES, White Stripes...blatent, especially on the tune \\"Apple Tree\\") all jump out at me when I hear these songs. But there's always that haunting Jack White vocal that somehow ruins my experience when listening. I even hear White Stripe-ish music in most of the songs. I wish I could just get these thoughts out of my brain and enjoy the experience.<br /><br />This shouldn't keep any true rock fan from buying this modern classic.<br /><br />Minds Eye<br /><br />Colossal<br /><br />Minds Eye<br /><br />Witchcraft<br /><br />Dimension<br /><br />& White Unicorn<br /><br />Are all solid rock tunes that I would have no problem sneaking onto some Gangsta Rap lovers ipod, in my effort to convert them to the \\"Rock\\" side of life.<br /><br />Hey, I realize that this is the way the lead singer sings, and I really do like The White Stripes. Still, I'm looking for total originality from a new and upcoming band. Imitation may be the best form of compliment, but spare me the copy-cat vocals on this one.<br /><br />3-stars for: Distortion, heavy without being mind-numbing, well written songs, $7.99 @ BestBuy, destin to become a \\"Classic\\" rock favorite in future years.ck\\" side of life. <br /> <br />Hey, I realize that this is the way the lead singer sings, and I really do like The White Stripes. B000EULJLU|4.0|I've listened to the album three times now and feel a little bit disappointed after anticipating this for five long years.  The album is good but just doesn't stick with me as Lateralus did.  I feel that the only songs that hold this album together are Vicarious, Jambi and The Pot.  10,000 days is a beautiful piece of music but would have been better placed towards the end of the album, much like Reflection on Lateralus.  Rosetta Stoned and Right in Two have yet to grow on me and the rest of the album is short segue ways and filler.  What's missing is the organic growth and climax that many of the songs on Lateralus had.  That album was stitched together perfectly well where all songs formed an organic whole in sequence.  I dont feel that from 10,000 days.  Perhaps I am unfairly comparing this album to Lateralus but after five years how can I not expect something better?  Every album from Tool was better than the previous, evolving on elements only partially devleved into in the prior records.  Of course I will still go see them live in NYC this month but I was surprised that the setlist for the tour contains only four songs from the new album, the rest from Aenima and Lateralus.  Well I still love Tool but I doubt I will be playing this album another five years from now.  Hopefully, they can put out another album a year or two early next time.
B000EULJLU|5.0|I've always been just a casual Tool fan. (And never a fan of Perfect Circle.) I've never bought their albums on the first day of their release, or for that matter in the first months, but I do own them all. I just happened to be in BestBuy today and seen it sitting on the shelf in that strange packaging for $9.99. Hearing \\"Vicarious\\" on The Bone (107.7 KSAN) here in the San Francisco Bay Area, made me decide that I was going to buy the album. Why not?<br /><br />From my very first play, I decided that this is now my favorite Tool album, dropping Aenima into the number 2 slot.<br /><br />I've read the other reviews and yep, the songs are long and it chews up a big chunk of time to listen to it, but it's so full of variety, and not one clunker on the disc. I usually tend to hate first singles off of albums, but \\"Vicarious\\" is my favorite at this time...after 3 listens and a 1/2 while I cooked dinner and the wife listened in the living room.<br /><br />I highly recommend this disc to Tool fans. If they find the disc not up to snuff with your older Tool albums, just relax. Take a few breaths, open your mind and remember, we wouldn't want Tool, or any band for that matter to put out the same CD with every release. (Can anybody say \\"Godsmack\\". Sure, I knew you could!)<br /><br />You've waited 5 long years for this release. Give yourself some time. It's really a great work...Thanks TOOL guys!

B000ETQRCM|5.0|Pearl Jams self titled release is definitely one of their best albums yet.  In their 40s now, the band still sounds fresh and are just rocking the hell out of this album.  Everything that makes PJ great is here.  Great lyrics, flat out amazing vocals, crunching guitar riffs, cool solos, nice solid bass playing, and AWESOME drums. The thing that makes the album so great for me is the voice of Eddie Vedder.  On the bands last 2 albums, Ed didnt have to be aggressive in his singing.  On this album he reached his most powerful yet.  Its quite amazing to hear him go from singing aggressive to very melodic and beautiful.  Along with Eddie, the rest of the band are in top form here.  Everyone gives it their all.  Mike and Stone havent sounded more alive with their guitar playing in a long time.  So, if youre already a Pearl Jam fan and you werent pleased with their last 2 releases, you will most likely love this.  Its A LOT like their 1998 album Yield in terms of overall vide and energy. Great, solid, and very cool album.
